You have to arrive by tuktuk or taxi. And then the time the countryside was cleared... 05:30. Around 06:00 the sun glowing and illuminating these hills where tea trees are king. It's just beautiful. 1/2 of contemplation of nature.

column8: Want a cuppa tea with Mr Lipton
column11: What an amazing part of Haputale - the Tuk Tuk üõ∫ was challenging we used Ashys Tuk Tuk üõ∫ Tours and he was amazing and a safe driver.  The view down Mr Lipton's Seat was fantastic as was wondering around the tea plantation - great experience

column8: A Must-Visit for Nature and Tea Lovers!
column11: As a tour guide, I‚Äôve had the pleasure of visiting Lipton‚Äôs Seat countless times, and it never fails to impress. Perched high in the lush tea country of Sri Lanka, this iconic viewpoint offers breathtaking panoramas of rolling hills and verdant tea estates. On a clear day, you can see all the way to the southern coast! The journey to the top is just as magical, winding through scenic tea plantations and charming villages. I always recommend arriving early in the morning to catch the sunrise‚Äîit‚Äôs an unforgettable experience. The small tea shop near the summit serves a perfect cup of Ceylon tea, adding a cozy touch to the visit. It‚Äôs a fantastic spot for photography, relaxation, or simply soaking in the serene ambiance. Whether you‚Äôre a nature enthusiast, a tea lover, or a traveler seeking peace, Lipton‚Äôs Seat is a destination you‚Äôll treasure. Tip: Wear comfortable shoes and bring a light jacket; it can get chilly up there!

Great views on a nice day if you are early enough.  The clouds come in quite quickly.  We got a tuk tuk from Ella very early in the morning.  It was a pleasant trip but can get quite bumpy with hair pin corners, I would not self drive here.  Stunning views and you can walk up if you like but I think they still try and charge you a fee.  The tea plantations are such an incredible view and the tea pickers were starting for the day and kids off to school waving.  There was a man at the top trying to tell you the history and offer to take photos for you all for a fee of course.  Then there is a little blue shed that sell you tea with jaggery which is really nice and some food for a really reasonable price.  Sit there and watch the cheeky monkeys.  Was worth the early morning.

The view from the observation deck is of course beautiful, the view of the area in good weather is impressive. I drank tea, and I was treated to tasty foods, which I inadvertently left on the table, which the monkey immediately took advantage of and confiscated. The road to the exam room. I liked it even better. Serpentine goes through the black and green tea plantations owned by the tea factory, which is given tours as it is operational. Along the way, you can stop, watch tea pickers work, take pictures of them. Ticket costs Rs. 550 and Rs. 100 per tuk-tuk. You can walk a few kilometres, but most people drive tuk-tuks. From Haputale railway station to Lipton Sit and back she traded for Rs. 2,200, then decided to go to Ella for Rs. 5,500. Took it right to the hotel door.

column8: Advice if driving your own tuk tuk from Ella
column11: We loved our visit.  The view was stunning at the top, luckily we had a nice clear morning.   If your driving your own tuk tuk from Ella, google maps will send you directly there.  However this track although the prettiest landscape in sri lanka through the tea plantations and villages ,  is incredibly rough and rather tricky at times.  Definitely not for everyone.  If you put via Haputale into maps it will  take you on a much better road.  Still very pretty and rough at  the top but that's the fun of the trip.  We enjoyed our tea and snack at the top.

Visiting Lipton‚Äôs Seat was an unforgettable experience! Perched high in Sri Lanka‚Äôs Haputale region, this iconic viewpoint offers breathtaking panoramic views of rolling tea plantations, misty valleys, and distant mountain ranges. The journey through the Dambatenne Tea Estate was just as beautiful as the destination itself. Whether you hike or take a tuk-tuk, the winding paths through lush green tea fields make for an amazing adventure. We took a tuk tuk and it was an adventurous ride, the roads can get very steep. However when you go to the top you can have a breathtaking view. We went in the afternoon and it was too misty with slight rain. If you're in Sri Lanka‚Äôs hill country, Lipton‚Äôs Seat is an absolute must-visit! It‚Äôs a place where nature, history, and serenity come together perfectly.

Lovely to take a tuk tuk ride over the beautiful green lush tea plantations to the view point at Liptons seat. Great views and photo opportunities from there . People were hiking up ‚Ä¶good for them ‚Ä¶but they were much younger and fitter than us ! Glad we booked a tuk tuk As it‚Äôs a fair climb !

TUK TUK TRAUMA TOUR We had a tuk tuk tour from  Bandarawele through the tea plantations to the Lipton estate across 2 hours of unmade and derelict road. We were shaken, bartered and bruised by the time we arrived. Top tip: Take a car to  Haputale then a tuk tuk, or better still, drive all the way up. The toilets were filthy, no water no flush. The tea room is dirty and a scam pit. We bought 2 cups of tea for 200rs. On paying we offered a 500rs note we were told they had no change!!ü§¨ We have loved our trip and everything we have done in this lovely country, but this was a very disappointing end.
A place worth of visiting and grate walking track with so much senic view. Nice lush tea gardens all around and can see 360¬∞ view  at the peak.
Very gorgeous scenery in the tea highlands. You can taste tea right at the peak. It is about an hours drive from Ella. The tea estate are gorgeous.

Lipton seat located at the top of Haputhale. You need to travel a few more Km's from the town. A lovely place with an attractive atmosphere. You can see several provinces in Sri Lanka  from this place. The place is located in a tea estate. Washrooms available. It's better to travel by SUV vehicle. Small parking area and narrow roads, be careful.

There is a long seat where the owner Mr Lipton of the estate spend some time by resting himself. This location is specific where on a clear day, two provinces cold be seen on to left Uva privince and to the right side the Sabaragamuwa province. Also the Southern province could also be seen at a far distance by looking straight. Cars,vans and buses are parked near the factory of the estate and we have to travel by three wheelers that are on hire as some roads leading to the location is narrow or two vehicles on opposte direction cannot move. The scenery along the road too was nice.

Upon arriving at Lipton's Seat, the first thing that struck me was the sheer beauty of the surrounding landscape. The tea plantations, stretching as far as the eye can see, were a vibrant tapestry of greens and golds, with workers plucking tea leaves under the sun. The air was fresh and invigorating, invigorating my senses as I made my way to the viewpoint.

Spectacular experience. We're up at 5:00 am. We had booked a tuk-Tuk the day before through the accommodation in Haputale. It takes you an hour to get there. That's 16 km from Haputale. Calculate the time to arrive just as the sun rises. The road is narrow and winding, and bumpy. LKR 550 per person and LKR 100 per tuk-tuk are payable. The views are spectacular. Photos of the sunrise. Photo with the figure of Mr. Lipton. There is a coffee machine where you have a tea for 100 LKR. And you appreciate it. Because it's cold. Take windbreakers or sweatshirt. Meet the driver at the Dambatenne Tea Factory and walk back between tea terraces. It's 8 km downhill. If you get your bearings right you can take some shortcuts to cross between the tea fields. If not, follow the road and there is no loss. You'll cross paths with women who go to work. They'll ask you to take a picture to give them some money. At the end you can visit the Dambatenne Tea Factory. And at the end, with the tuk-tuk return to Haputale.

This was one of the highlights of our tour. By Tuk Tuk the 16 kms up to Lipton seat felt precarious at times, with bumpy and narrow roads. But seeing the tea plantation covering every square inch was awe inspiring.We had a wonderful drivers who was quite funny and knowledgeable and whose English was very good. 6000 feet above sea level we were above clouds and the views were spectacular. It was a Sunday so no one was working but people were going about their daily routine.

A recommended early morning walk to watch the sunrise over the mountains. The light on the tea plantations is enchanting. Going there by tuk-tuk almost to the top then making the descent to the factory on foot, crossing the plantations, the gathering villages that bustle in the early morning is worth the detour. Meet children who join their school in uniform. Allow a few pens or notebook to donate to the school you pass by can be a good thing for the locals too.

We went from Haputale on a scooter. Me, a 43 year old mum and 15 year old son on the back. I am not the best scooterdriver, but it was doable. Only  the last bit between the ticket office and liptonseat was sometimes not very good road. But doable. We started around 7 in Haputale, arrived around 8 on lipton seat. Because we where early, we had a very good view. We had breakfast in the cafe on top. Walked around and when we left at ten o clock it was cloudy. So make sure you go early. Breakfast was cheap and good, with Lipton tea. The way towards is nice to see the teapickers in action. The way back we enjoyed driving in the clouds and smelling clouds and tea mixed together. Absolutely worth it!

Beautiful drive through the tea plantation As roads are small and broken at some places driving is dangerous. Once you reach the mountain top it‚Äôs a beautiful view. Three wheelers tuktuk are the best to drive there. The tea shop isn‚Äôt hygienic, so better to avoid having tea from there Buy vegetables and fresh fruits on the way. Enjoy the drive

This was one of the nicest things we did on our fantastic holiday in Sri Lanka. We decided to organize a tuktuk to take us to the top to watch the sun rise and we had the most perfect weather with views for miles. It was a truly magical and quite emotional experience. After tea at the little tea house at the top we walked down to the tea factory which, what with the lack of health and safety measures and the fact that nothing has changed there in probably 75 years, was the best factory tour that I have ever done. Lastly some time spent talking with a bunch of tea picking ladies who were very open and welcoming to us gave us further insight into their daily lives. Thoroughly well worth the crazy early start.

Had a super fun trip. Take a tuk tuk all the way up to the beautiful green surroundings of tea plantations. Women who had just come from the plantations had their bags weighed to see how much they had picked. Nice experience.

V.Sivakanth drove us with his TUK TUK to the "Lipton Seat" It was a real pleasure...!!! 077 2554321 He is really very kind and professional. üëç üëè It allowed us to stop often to take wonderful photos. I highly recommend these services, you will be charmed by their professionalism his efficiency and kindness...!!! Thank you very much for this unforgettable day...! üòä Danielle & Luc

Unfortunately, the overcast weather did not allow us to enjoy the view but the atmosphere was nevertheless "mystical"! It's a place very exposed to the wind, fortunately there is a small shelter with the possibility of having tea (quite bad though). We went up there in a tuktuk for sunrise (missed) but we think it's worth the effort of waking up in the early morning. In addition, it is a good starting point for a magnificent walk through the plantations (the clouds have gradually left), even with overcast weather the atmosphere is cozy and relaxing. Take the opportunity to go to the Dambatenne factory.

We were given a very friendly welcome by Akila and we went to Lipton's Seat in his comfortable tuk tuk. Before that we went to the Rawana waterfalls and the Nine Arches Bridge. Akila was very accommodating and explained a lot to us. We would be happy to come back any time.

Nestled amidst lush greenery, Lipton Seat offers a breathtaking panoramic view that's worth every moment and penny spent. Taking a tuk-tuk ride up the winding roads adds to the adventure, making the journey as delightful as the destination itself. Surrounded by serene tea gardens, the experience is a perfect blend of natural beauty and historical charm. Whether you're a tea enthusiast or simply seeking a tranquil escape, Lipton Seat promises an unforgettable excursion that's truly worth your time and money.

Pretty good views. 550 rupee entrance fee per person feels a little steep, like the climb (we walked there from Haputale), but rather underwhelming. The tea in the little cafe at the top was nice though.  As it should be on one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs premium tea estates‚Ä¶

After an expensive bone-pummelling tuk-tuk ride to the top of the ridge what did we see? A concrete platform and view that can be matched or exceeded in most places in the world. Bigged up and disappointing is what it is.

One of the many facets of Sri Lanka, the tea fields. Lipton Seat can only be visited by tuktuk due to the narrowness of the roads. This road crosses typical villages and we were lucky to arrive during the weighing of the tea collected by mainly women, very little paid. The ascent continues on very narrow concrete tracks. The view is superb. As for Sir Lipton, a faded statue, nothing special. The view and the villages are the real attractions.
A must for nature lovers. The view and impressions of the completely green surroundings in the mountains are breathtakingly beautiful
After visiting this tea plantation place by tuktuk... you will no longer drink it like before. The walk is definitely worth it. At the end of the climb the view is magnificent. To do at all costs.

We were all ready to go to see the Lipton seats but thru half way a person said  that our vehicle was too low and could get damaged, so we had to come back, it would have been helpful if their was this information as for which type of wehicle could go their so we could have planned the trip accordingly

Arriving by train from Ella, we took a tuk tuk to take us to the top of Lipton's Seat. Then we walked back down to the tea factory to be able to enjoy the landscapes of the plantations as much as possible. I advise you to go back down like this, you meet the villagers and employees, quietly admire the landscapes. We took our time, it took us between 1 hour and 1 hour 30 minutes.
Great experience, great view. We went up in a tuk-tuk and saw a lot, tea pickers, how the tea was weighed. Definitely recommended when the weather is good.

A low relates to the fact that the weather was appalling on the day we went to the top by tuk tuk. We couldn‚Äôt see a thing. We took a couple of photos by the statue and went back down, after having to pay to use the toilet, but avoiding the cafe. I‚Äôm sure the views are wonderful, but my rating has to be based on experience and not the opinion of other and instagram pictures. A pity as we had been looking forward to this trip

A worthwhile trip - the view alone is priceless! We had Sharitdeen Saref (+94 72 6203142) as a tuk-tuk driver - perfect! He speaks great English and told us and showed us a lot about tea cultivation! Including a little photo shoot for our photo albums ‚ò∫Ô∏è He is a safe and careful driver who I can wholeheartedly recommend to everyone!
The views were amazing and the ride was long but beautiful. They charge 500 rupee per head and more for vehicles.
Very accessible site, we arrived from Ella by Tuktuk (around 1h00 / 7000rps) to the top. Entrance is 500rps per person

Fantastic views all the way up to Lipton‚Äôs Seat and great to talk to some of the tea pickers. It‚Äôs well worth taking the time to walk part of it and seek out the tea pickers, who often have their entire families working on the estate.

Eighteen of us, travelling with Flamingo Tours, visited the Lipton's seat in the morning on 11th June 2023.  The coach we travelled in stopped near Dambetenna Tea Factory.  From there we hired tuk-tuks up to the Lipton's Seat - a distance of seven and a half kilometres.  Entrance tickets cost Rs 100 for locals and Rs 500 for foreigners. Up there on top, the views were picturesque, scenic, and vividly pleasing to the eye. Looking down into the clouds, we felt as if we were high above and in heaven!  It certainly was a view like no other! The statue of seated Thomas Lipton lies on top, where visitors sit by the statue to take photographs with him by the side. There is a small shop that serves roti, wade and tea.  We enjoyed some wade and tea there during our two hours stay in heaven before returning to the earth by tuk-tuk.
The way up to the top ..full of beautiful tea gardens and view is awsome from Lipton's seat of course on a clear day
very beautiful view tuktuk up is around 2000LKR round trip we had luck to get there quite early and be the only tourists on top

The trip to go up is amazing and worth doing it. However dont do the mistake and buy a ticket to enter what they call "lipton seat". There is nothing special there while someone will try to grab money from you when serving food without asking, pay attention this os a trap
Wonderful spot, great drive up. Unfortunately, the mist didn't clear on the day we visited so we couldn't capture the best views.
Beautiful place i ever went.when you go there you can see 5 province.thats awesome.whether also changing quickly .love this place
We had a fantastic driver who took us all the way up to the top of the lipton's hill. Lipton's seat isn't any special but the views there are spectacular (provided that there isn't mist).

Beautiful landscape before entering the Lipton seat view point. Entrece fee is 500 rupies pp. + vehicle charge. View Point is mostly covered with mist. In the view point there is a small resturent. But before order it better ask prices. Then they can't over charge you. You can go until the ticket counter without pay and can see nice landscapes without  enter the view point and it won't do big difference. And be careful the dambethanna tea factory. It is a scam. They will overcharge you

It is a very interesting journey up to the summit to get to Lipton's seat.  Driving through the tea plantains along tiny roads to Lipton's Seat is an experience in itself.  Unfortunately, the day that we went, it was cloudy in the valley below and we didn't get the wonderful views.  However, we enjoyed seeing Mr Lipton and what we could see of the countryside.  Even though it was cloudy at altitude, it was worth the visit.

It was about an hour bumpy tuk tuk ride up and another hour bumpy tuk tuk ride down. The view is ok if you are lucky not to have a hazy / grey / rainy day. Not worth the trip or the view. Many places in Haputhale to get a better view without the bumpy ride. Note: I am writing this review after completing 15 days holiday in Sri Lanka; therefore, I have considered all pro and cons.

You are led to believe the "cups of tea" at the viewpoint are part of the Lipton Seat viewpoint. They are not. This is just a scam where they will offer you tea and then charge you a ridiculous price for it. Many many dollars for a pot of tea... And then become confrontational. These scammers are not part of Lipton and its amazing that they are let inside to scam people each day. DO NOT FALL FOR IT Secondly. Need the toilet? There is a guy stood outside and only white people must pay. This place was a joke and made the entirely of Sri Lanka look bad. Shame on you!
nice view but warning to car drivers...  the road is very hard to drive up its a single file road so when another vehicle is coming down its hard to like make room
The drive was a nightmare. Do not recommend traveling by vehicle to the spot. Scenic view but would have opted to go by foot if we had known how difficult the ride was to the top.
nice panoramic view rough road but good journey. better if you have 4*4 not ideal if raining. interesting.

We took the 7am local bus from Kelburne to Dambetenna Factory and then a Tuk Tuk (Rs. 800 one way without bargaining!) to Lipton's Seat. We admired the clear view and had Dhal vade and roti at the shop and walked down. The views are amazing and it's lovely to walk among the tea plantation. We took two short cuts down stone steps. We got back to Kelburne by 11am. Beautiful day!
This is a great place to visit on a clear day with stunning views. The journey up is best by tuc-tuc as the road is very narrow - it's a great scenic journey up and well worth the visit.

Lipton's seat is a scenic view point situated at the edge of Dambethenna tea estate. Sir Thomas Lipton was used to enjoy the view from this place when he was at Dambethenna estate. The place is situated about 15 km from the town. Haputhale-Dambethenna buses go till Dambethenna tea factory. You can get a tuk-tuk from Dambethenna tea factory or walk though tea estate (It is about 6 km but there are short cuts) to reach the place. You can get view of five province from Lipton's seat. There is a separate observation desk built at more higher place.  Better visit there at morning hours as it takes only few minutes to cover the view with mist. It is worth to visit at Dambethenna tea factory as well.

A must see attraction if you're in the area.  The Victorian tea making factory is still working and is a great example of colonial investment (whether you agree or not with the historical context). It's in a working plantation and there are fabulous views of the surrounding area from its mountain-top location.

Tuk tuk was 1500LKR return. Would advise getting up and watching the stars before waiting for the sunrise. Lots of monkeys around - don't be a Pino and feed them. This encourages aggressive behaviour and they were already trying to snatch food and bags.

If you are willing to have a little harder hike or a ride you may go Lipton‚Äôs Seat since the end of the hike will let you have a heaven feeling since that‚Äôs really worth to go to the top of the mountain along the tea state cause it‚Äôs really nice view on the top.higly recommended for nature lover photographers and travelers for breathtaking sceneries.

We started our journey from a hotel in Ella at 455am and arrived the peak after a short transit to board a tuk tuk in order to get all the way up to the Lipton‚Äôs seat. The temperature was cold, around 8 degrees celsius so please be prepared. At the peak, its just a viewpoint to take a great sunrise shot, there is a local cafe which serves some local savouries and hot cups of tea and coffee, nothing fancy. Be warned, there are no restrooms at this point and the closest one is at the tea factory 30min drive away that only opens at 8am, and you will need 20 sri lankan rupees for that.
A wonderful place to go down from the Lipton Seat to the Tea factory. It will take you a couple of hours, but it's worth it!  The views are unforgettable.
Stunning view from this point. you can go by foot but by tuk tuks i better option i guess. up on the hill is small restaurant where you can enjoy your cup of tea.

Stunning views over huge area of tea plants . Liptons height is on 1900 meters. You can see the picking of the tea leaves by women. They earn 40 rupees per kilo. They pic up to19 Kilo a day. You can se the very old fashion factory following how the tea is dried cut and fermented. It was really worthwhile to go there.
Really recommend a trip to Lipton‚Äôs Seat, and from there walk down through the fields to the Tea Factory to catch the bus back to Haputale.

Lipton's seat is highest point of Haputale in Sri Lanka. you can see nice view with cloudy. When you plan to go early morning you can view amazing sun rising too. Tea estate around this place and see many area in sri lanka if it is clear from mites. You need to buy ticket at the entrance.

Another beautiful place in Haputale. From this location you can visit five provinces of Sri Lanka simultaneously. It is one of the largest tea estates in Sri Lanka. We invite you to visit this place if you are visiting Sri Lanka.

Very nice view even though it was cloudy, the way up was absolutely amazing.  However we could gave skipped the caf√©. The workers lured us in which was expected but it was unnecessarily expensive for a cup of tea and some small portion of Rotti. When we paid the waiter refused to give me the change because I'm a woman and insisted on waiting for my fianc√© which i found upsetting, and then he expected a tip.

We did this the lazy way with a bone rattling tuk-tuk ride to the top and then back down. Beautiful views, absolutely breath-taking, photographs don‚Äôt do it justice you need to see it to believe. With a morning visit, with bright sun and clear skies you can see all the way to the southern beaches of Sri Lanka from here. It actually got a bit cold when we visited and we were glad that the lookout at the top asked us if we wanted some team & rottis üòé Some hot food and drink was most welcome! Thoroughly recommend.

We did Liptons Seat the lazy way which was to take a Turk-Tuk up and then walk down.  It is so worth it to stay at Haputale to do this walk and see the views which are spectacular. The walk down is a breeze and is a wonderful experience.

Go early in the morning, such a beautiful spot and very peaceful. We were lucky enough to experience a perfectly clear sunny morning. The small cafe/hut at the top also serves good roti, samosa and of course tea. We traveled by Tuk Tuk from our home-stay in Ella.
we went there for sunrise, it was absolutely amazing. We walk down through the tea plantation , very peaceful.

We had our driver take us all the way up to Liptons Seat. No need for a tuk tuk if you have a car. Unfortunately for us it was super misty so we didn‚Äôt have the amazing view we had heard of.  The locals told us the mornings are much better than the afternoons so I would advise you to go early. The drive up was completely beautiful so we still enjoyed some amazing views and there is a cute tea shop at the top with really good samosas!

This is my second visit by tuk tuk safari and It's a nice place to go again and again. We can see few provinces from there clearly and most wonderful mountain view . On the way to Lipton seat there are some other beautiful views which can see from the road.

Lipton's Seat is situated in Dambetenna Estate, Haputale. You can take the Dambethenna bus from Bandarawela that passes via Haputale Town where it would take you upto the Dambetenna tea factory. It's a 7km hike from the factory to Lipton's Seat from there. There is another bus from Haputale to Lipton's Seat that would take you upto the ticket counter. Then it's a 1.5km walk from there onwards. The local cost of a ticket per person is Rs.30. But the most likely option is to take a tuk tuk from Dambetenna Factory to Lipton's Seat. The cost may vary depending on your bargaining skills. It ranges from Rs.600 to Rs.900. They view is stunning if you manage to go before the mist covers the whole area. The best time would be around 9.00 a.m. There are many overlooking mountains, lakes and you can even get a view of Hambantota up from there. You can sit beside the statue of Sir Thomas Lipton holding a cup of tea and snap some pictures too.

WOw! What a view.. Never knew Sri Lanka had such a beautiful view until u start climbing to Haputale in the foggy roads.. Its a must in your bucket list.. Just Heaven on Earth!! The locals were really friendly and nice.

The place was named after Sir Thomas Lipton who has loved to come to this lookout point and for whom a memorial has been erected there. It shows the British founder of the trademark ‚ÄúLipton‚Äù sitting while holding a cup of tea. From Lipton‚Äôs seat you can have a stunning view of surrounding mountains and reservoirs. Clouds might fog the views at times. We advice to ask the locals about the expected weather conditions. They¬¥ll know better than the well known weather websites. There is a basic tea stall which serves breakfast, with tea of course. A final advice: bring some extra warm clothes, it gets quite chilly in the morning.
The drive up was amazing, the actual look out was overated but the drive up through all the tea plants was really special

Many people come to see the views and to experience either sunrise or sunset.  We arrived a bit later than sunrise but had the tremendous experience of taking a tuk tuk from the Dambatenne Estate Factory and office to the top -- not to be missed.  We then experienced the incredible fog which came and went (mostly came) but appreciated the views when they were available.  Don't miss the dosas and somasas (along with the super coffee) served in the little shop right at the parking lot....all were terrific.

First of all, must see place while you are in Haputale. Would like to share few pointers which would be helpful. Make sure weather is good otherwise you won't be able to see the surroundings. I took bus from Haputale town towards Dabetenna Tea factory. Bus stops behind the Haputale Bus stand. There is a another option, you can take another bus which goes till entrance of Lipton Seat. Bus leaves around 7.30am from Haputale Bus terminal. This bus goes to a village near Lipton Seat. I walked from Dabetenna Tea factory to Lipton Seat. Distance is around 9KM one way and back. If you are not a fan of walking, you may take a tuk tuk from Dabetenna Tea factory. Cost around 700LKR... They will wait for you too bring you back to Dabetenna. Try to be there early as possible to view the sunrise. Wonderful views. There is a small canteen at Lipton Seat, you can try simple breakfast too.
We went with a tuktuk upto the Lipton seat. The most beautiful views! When your in Ella you should experience thuis.

The view from the top by Lipton's statue is pretty and shows off tea plantations in every direction. There are places along the way (walking or riding) where you can look around and wander a bit through the rows of tea plants.
Such a wonderful location,always better if you can visit early morning ( 6am -9am ).Road is narrow but still it‚Äôs motorable upto view point,üöó Amazing tea garden + 360 view point üá±üá∞üå±
Advisable to travel up and down by tuktuk. (RS1500 for to and fro trip). Wonderful sunrise at mid of the mountain , whereby tuktuk driver stop by to allow me to take a photo.

Well worth the walk up the hill but if that is going to be too much for ya, you can drive right up to the top! How ever you get there it will be worth it 100% it.  The little family tea shoppie at the top is well worth taking morning tea at.

One of the most beautiful Location in the central province of Sri Lanka. wonderful walk through the mist and the tea plantations. Then you will reach to the Lipton's Seat. I would prefer to hire a motorcycle to travel this wonderful breathtaking experience The nature of the access to this place is ideal for walking or traveling by a bike and I invite everyone to come and see this beautiful place and enjoy the panoramic views

This is one of my favorite places in SE Asia. We only spent one morning there, but I would be happy to return for multiple consecutive days just to walk around and enjoy the views. Many people only speak of Lipton Seat as a place to go in this area, but I was unimpressed by the actual Lipton Seat. It essentially is just a view-point of the land looking off the mountain at the land below, not a view of the rolling hills patterned with tea trees. The true beauty of this area is the entire tea estate you go through en route to Lipton Seat. The best time to go is the morning‚Äîthe earlier the better. It started to get clouded over by 10 AM, so if you are walking, arrive early. I would recommend arriving to the Dambetenne Tea Factory between 7:00 - 8:00 AM (or earlier). Then, just start walking up to road, which is about 7km to the top. There are tuk-tuks which can take you up or down, either for a round trip quick ride to the top or by walking one way and riding the other. However, you would likely miss a lot of the wonderful views in a tuk-tuk. We leisurely walked up and walked down in about 4 hours, and stopped for tea and appetizers at the top (which were delicious). Along the way down, we decided to get off the road and walk down the same paths as many of the workers picking the leaves and it was absolutely wonderful to interact with them. They were so friendly and welcoming and wanted to chat with us, encouraging us to come with them as they continued to walk and work. It‚Äôs one of the most beautiful place in SL, in my opinion‚Äîand the women working in the fields are equally beautiful and filled with generosity and love. It‚Äôs the true embodiment of Sri Lanka.

All the effort to get up there is to see a  block of concrete as the statute has been removed for refurbishment.   However the location offers fabulous panoramic views of five dfiferent regions of Sri Lanka, that to if the weather is kind and the day is clear and bright with no mist.
Beatifull landscapes, full of green trees of tea, high mountains, very poor people- woman has payment for 9 kilo tea leaves only 900 lkr
The road to up is one of the most beautifull what i have ever seen, its about 10 km between Tea plantations and workers houses. On the top is restaurant and you can enjoy tea and beautifull view.
Sensational views and a really authentic experience.Take a tuk tuk up and then walk part of the way back down. It is lovely to walk amongst the meticulously kept tea bushes. Highly rated!

We drove up to the Lipton seat which took approximately an hour. The view was  rather appreciable all through out the drive and gave an interesting  view from the top. The trip was worth it though my wife was a little scared.
Best place enjoy great service and fresh ingredients tea nature wow good views also I will come again
what a great nature in Lipton sheet amazing view and cool place, good feeling everything perfectly. ..

Very good views. We took a Tuk Tuk up and then walked down. Despite being relatively high up it is quite hot, but well worth doing the walk through the tea fields in at least one direction. Tuk Tuk ride up felt quite expensive.

While the Lipton's Seat itself is a fantastic location,  there are a number of equally gorgeous viewpoints along the winding estate road to stop and enjoy. From Lipton's Seat,  you can observe the southern plains of the island as well as Nuwara Eliya and Namunukula mountain ranges,  offering a near 360 degree views. You should ideally catch the sun rise,  which needs an early start, or should be there before the mist sets in. Don't forget to visit the  Dambethenna Tea factory on the way back and also enjoy a cup of tea and local snacks from the small shop right in front.

Ella and Haputale (Liptons Chair) are on the same railway tract and you can visit Liptons seat when you stay in Ella. It is recommended to take a tuk tuk to the place which consume 45 min. It is better way to get threre a the road is winding and narrow and advised to get off your vehicle at Haputale. Lipton sat here when John Lipton, The owner of the estate then to relax himself. Yes, it is a fantastic location where you can see very long distances down hill as it is in a elevated place,. Seeing many angle views and how far you can see is depended on the mist/ fog. It is better to avoid late evenings and early mornings.

So i took the train from Ella to Haputhale which is a short scenic ride and from Haputale town towards "Dambetenna tea factory" then to Lipton's seat, in a tuk tuk which cost me around 1000 LKR and WOW the sceneries were amazing. Lipton's seat is the highest place of this tea planted area and said the owner of this this tea plantation(Thomas Lipton) use this place to monitor his plantations work. Early morning is the best time to visit there. Wonderful place surrounded by tea plantations. 5 surrounding provinces are visible to the mountain peak.
We go there amazing looks and great opening my This place amazing sri Lanka highly recommend that's place

The best of tea fields on Sir Lanka. We were there in the afternoon and it is true that the view was not good - on the one side was huge fog so we couldn't see anything. Despite this it was great walk, amazing tea fields and I fell in love with it.

The view point at the top is great and you can get a cup of tea at any price you think it's worth it. The paved road to the top and back is less interesting. It's more adventurous if you follow the trails through the tea plantations and some of the hidden unpaved roads.

We took a tuk tuk from Haputale and got dropped off at the ticket booth under the top of the viewpoint. We walked up the last 1,5 km and enjoyed the splendid view. Drink tea on the top and the guys will ask you to pay whatever you think is reasonable. No set prices. We hiked the 8 km back through the tea plantations going east around the south side of the peak back to west where the tea factory is. This was our favorite place and walking during our 6-day hill country stay. We started Ella by train, it's an hour scenic journey to Haputale. Then we got a tuktuk almost to the top (20 min); for the last km there's an entrance fee and by tuktuk+driver you pay more. Even there were clouds and vapor the views are just stunning. There is a cafe where you got local snacks and tea automatically just as you sit down. It's a cheap place. We walked all the way down until the tea factory. It's a pleasant 8km walk with incredible scenery; we could stop every minute to watch the unbelievably green fields. At the tea factory there are a lot of tuktuks but there is also a bus which goes until Bandarawela (40min) where you can switch to bus going through Ella (20min).

Took the bus from Haputale to Dambethenna (quite easy) early in the morning and then walked up to the top. We watched a couple of tourists who went there by Tuktuk, took a few pictures (the same pictures everyone has) and went back down - they missed the good part, which is walking the whole way up on the street (easy to find, just follow the signs). Took us about 2 hours, and every 10 meters you get a new astonishing view. At Lipton's Seat you can have a cup of tea which surprisingly was not as much of a ripoff as we expected (50 rupies, but you actively have to say no to the food unless you want it). We hiked back down through the fields which we enjoyed even more. Do yourself a favour and take some time to actually enjoy things instead of just rushing through the country to take perfect pictures for social media. Also, think of the environment before taking a Tuktuk.

we reached the place across the tea plantations,by tuk tuk ride,nearly we get 45 mins from Haputale city center to reach there,very nice location, morning time is very good,before 10.00am,because can see the view point without disturbance from the mist,early morning with the sun rise the view point able to see very clearly,very nice journey,have to pay around 150 lkr to visit this place

We went at sunrise and it was lovely.  We hiked down.  I think it would have been a hell of a hike up.  I would have needed the whole day. A great visit. We got a large tuk tuk to the top for 1,500 rupees (a normal tuk tuk is 1,000 one way) and then walked back down to the tea factory through beautifully manicured tea plantations. Liptons seat, views and surrounding tea plantations were AMAZING - nothing short of some of the most breathtaking scenery in Sri Lanka. We got a TukTuk from Haputale all the way up to Liptons Seat) one way flat fee of $1000 rupee). Our driver stopped at a couple of stunning view points on the way - view of Haputale Town and Eagle Rock notable mentions. Visited Liptons Seat and the journey towards it was amazing. On arrival at the top the views were breathtaking. I would say that this has to be in your top ten places to visit on your itinerary.

We came from Ella in a tuk - tuk and surprised I made it. This was some trip as the road was terrible. Other people went there by walking (good luck to them), vans and motor bike. If you take your time on the road I'm sure you'll take pleasure in reading many more. The experience made very special by the prevailing meteorological conditions with us sometimes above the clouds and within a few minutes clear blue skies A little off the usual tourist path but well worth the effort getting there

We had a very good driver. Many people leave there vehicle and hire a tuk-tuk for this final bit of the road. Be aware that there are limited toilet facilities at the top. Come prepared. There is a little tea shop at the summit and a seat with a statue of Sir Lipton where you can get a picture of yourself with the old planter. Because of its situation. My family and I were lucky enough to visit on a cool, clear day in February. Everything was arranged by Mai Globe Travels and we had a great time! We went to there in Octomber 2018. it was clear every side of the panaromic view. We stayed there while driving to Ella. We could see the wind mills in  very clearly though. The care taker informed us that the best time to visit.

We travelled all around Sri Lanka and Lipton Seat is one of the best things we saw.  The view  is just wonderful but the road to reach the top of the mountain it's even better. Just do it

The views are impressive however the real joy was walking down. So much to take in and see. We came under the top in the morning by tuk tuk - 900 from our hotel that was not far from the railway station. We had to walk about 1 km to get to the very top. The view of sunrise and all the hills covered in clouds was amazing. I really loved that. We had a cup of tea as well and they offer a small breakfast too :)

Interesting drive and then walk through an active tea plantation to the spot were Thomas Lipton came on a regular basis to commune with nature and survey his plantation.  Great views.  Can be combined with a visit to the original Lipton Tea Factory, still in operation and producing tea much as it would have been done decades ago.

This place literally took my breath away. Definitely one of the most gorgeous places of Sri Lanka. We got there by tuk-tuk from Haputale (for 1000lkr). It is approx. 45 minutes ascend by serpentine in tea plantations to height of 2200m. Whole route is jaw-dropping. Our driver stopped several times for us to let us enjoy various views. On the very top there is a platform from where 360 degree panoramic view opens in front of you and you can watch countless plantation hills disappearing in clouds below you and if weather is opportune you can even see ocean in the distance. We arrived in the afternoon and due to locals we were very lucky about weather conditions that day, cause usually people visit in the early morning to have the best visibility possible. I would recommend to do so, apparently it is not unusual thing to not be able to see further than 10 meters around you. Only thing apart from platform on top is small restaurant that will offer you one type of food that they made that day and delicious fresh local tea. There is some small fee for entering the seat, the experience is unforgettable and priceless though. This place is a must see!

Main Tip: If you've been to tea plantations in Nuwara Eliya you can skip Lipton's Seat. If not, I would make the trek out to visit. It was about a 1.5 hour tuk tuk ride from Ella on some scary roads once you get closer to Lipton's Seat. If you have a fear of heights - this is not the drive for you. I'd highly recommend taking a tuk tuk over a car if you can, the roads are extremely narrow  and I saw multiple cars have a difficult time getting through. If you are self-driving (as we were) I would absolutely discourage self-driving here because there is very little room for error. You can also take a bus to Liptons Seat (get off at Haputale) and take a tuk tuk from there. The view from the top by Lipton's statue is pretty and shows off tea plantations in every direction. You can either walk back down to the entrance (about 8km) to catch the bus or meet your ride or simply ride back in your tuk tuk once you are done looking around. There are places along the way (walking or riding) where you can look around and wander a bit through the rows of tea plants. Go early - the fog/mist rolled in around 9:30 am and I was told it can get bad enough later in the day that driving is difficult. Given those roads that is not a risk I'd ever want to take! Also people often take pictures of the tea ladies working but remember - they are paid the equivalent of less than $3 usd a day and they are not animals in a zoo who are performing for your entertainment.

1. Hire a scooter 1000-1500 rupies/24h plus full tank. 2. Start 8:00 from Ella 3. Google Maps / follow signs 4. First gate 30 rupies 5. Bumpy ride for ca 9 km 6. Last gate tickets 250 rupies for 2 persons 7. Pot of Tea 450 rupies. 8. Its totally worth it.
Very beautiful tea range with mountains top of green tea leaves and chilling windy point of haputale.

A great place to have a nice breathtaking 360 view . The place is around 15km away from Haputale. You can take the route via Dambetenna estate. You can drive your own vehicle (Heavy vehicles are not allowed) all the way to the top without any issue. The only thing is the road is very narrow & very difficult to cross over with a vehicle coming from opposite direction. On the top parking space is available for few vehicles. If you wish to use public transport service you can find a bus to Lipton Seat from Haputale.(Haputale - Bandara Eliya) You are lucky if you can take that direct bus since the service is not frequent. If it feels hard to find the bus simply ask a local. They are very friendly. They helped us a lot when we were visiting this area. If the bus is not available simply take the bus Bandarawela - Dambetenna which is running via Haputale. It will take you up to Dambetenna tea factory. For the rest you can hire a taxi or small buses running occasionally. If you prefer walking to the destination you have to walk about 8km. But walking may make you very tired as you have to climb up from the beginning to the end. If you chose hiring a taxi you can go to the top directly while if you chose bus you have to walk around 2km to reach the destination. You are required to buy tickets (for yourselves & vehicles)  at the entrance gate and the ticket is valid only for issued day. On the top there is a small shop & you can buy small things like water bottles, snacks from there. And a statue of Thomas Lipton is sitting on a bench is there & you can take photographs with him. Just above the small shop mentioned earlier there is a viewing deck & from there you can take a clear look around without any disturbance from trees. It is said to be that if there is no mist then we can see Several districts from here & Hambontota harbour too. But When I visit there there were some mist in some area. For me some mountains & few lakes were visible on one side. But the thing is I couldn't recognize any of those and any districts from there. :) Don't forget your camera when you visit there. You can have a huge collection of good shots. If you hope to return by bus don't forget to ask about the times of return buses while going up. Otherwise you may have to waste your time waiting for a bus.

We were based in Ella and having read a few reviews about going to liptons seat we decided we would try and do it as cheap as possible and here's what we did. Below prices are 1 person. I would defiantley reccomend doing the hike if you've got time it took us about 2 hrs up and 90 mins down. It made the views so much worth it! We got up there just before 11am a little bit misty but still had some clear breaks to take in the amazing views. We arrvived back in Ella around 4pm as we had just missed the 12.30pm train back to Ella and waited for the 14.15pm train. You can also do a tour of tea factory but we skipped this. So all in all the cost of the day excursion was 352rp per person. Pretty good I thought for about ¬£1.50.
A must visit place if you are around Bandarawela/Haputale. the road to Lipton seat is so beautiful. there is a tea shop at Lipton seat and you can have a nice sri Lankan tea with a stunning view
Beautiful surroundings.... Visit early in morning or evening time.  Narrow road but can move two vehicles.

We took a tuk tuk up from the tea factory and walked the 7k back.. a must do! The view from the top is 360 and was amazing! As per other posts , this is some of the most beautiful scenery in Sri Lanka. Walking down enables you to really appreciate the scenery, the tea plantations, the villages and their carefully tended allotments, the lady in red doing mountains of washing in the stream. Do it!

Road to Lipton seat is very narrow. However the views on the way are so beautiful .Its about 15-16 km from Haputale town.  Takes over 30 minutes to go up in a vehicle/A bus is travelling to some extent, Would not recommend to go in a Van as there are sharp bends,Tuk Tuks are available for hire. On top there is a small shops where you can have, Roti, Wade and tea.
We didn‚Äôt expect much from this visit and we were positively surprised from the view going up to the top!!! Just amazing!!

Took a tuktuk up for sunrise, enjoyed a packed breakfast up there then walked down a couple of kilometers before catching our tuktuk back to Haputale. Ride from Haputale took maybe 40 minutes? It‚Äôs not far but definitely a steep and windy road up! Gorgeous ride up, stunning views, and highly recommend walking at least part way down the road to fully enjoy the peacefulness and beauty of the tea fields. We thought it was one of the most beautiful places on our whole Sri Lanka trip. Highly recommend!!

We were staying in Ella and got the train to Haputale (100 Rs) then a tuk tuk from there to about 2km from the top (1200 Rs), there is a small entry fee. The hike is uphill through the plantation and beautiful. When we got there it wasn‚Äôt completely clear but we still had a great view - there‚Äôs a cafe that sells tea and Sri Lankan food which is very tasty and not overly priced. Walk down through the tea estate down to the tea factory was a pleasure.

I recommend going there by bus as it's the most convenient and adventures way. If you are traveling from Haputale (stay at White Monkey!), it will take you approximately 20min by bus and then another 20min of walking so that you've really earned the view. Go early in the morning to assure that no clouds block your view. And treat yourself with the delicious breakfast for a cheap price.
Check whether its a misty day or not before going there coz if its misty you will not see anything other than the white mist.

Our review focuses on the natural landscapes surrounding Lipton‚Äôs Seat. We spent about 30 seconds at the statue itself (after driving up there by Tuk Tuk). The real magic comes from walking down the mountain and taking in the breathtaking scenery. The tree plantations, the farms the women working on the plantations are just too amazing for words. Our photos don‚Äôt do the view justice. We have seen a myriad of stunning scenes since being in Sri Lanka, but this walk is not to be missed. Get there early morning (around 9:30am) so that you can do the walk before it gets too hot.

We took a tuk-tuk from Haputale to Liptons seat which is a very scenic drive up in the mountains and round hairpin bends. The view from Liptons seat is amazing but it's best to arrive early before the clouds obscure the views. It gets pretty chilly up there but there's a tea shop where you can get a warm drink and something to eat. It's just over 7km walk down to the Dambatanne tea factory where you can pick up a bus to Haputale, or carry on and walk back all the way to Haputale which we did, takes about 3 hours but it's all downhill through the tea plantations and is a lovely walk. Don't take a taxi/tuk-tuk there and back as you'll miss out on the splendour of the place.

Amazing views all around and walking inside tea plantations was really interesting. Make sure to go there before 7.30 AM for best view otherwise it will covered by clouds. Tiny narrow roads across the tea plantation bit of risky, therefore we kept our vehicle at hotel and took a tuck tuck that cost us Rs. 2000 that was actually unreasonable.
Visit at sunrise to get a great view - i's worth the early start.  Coming back down you get to see what you missed on the way up - the tea plantations and the workers

We went up there for sunrise from Haputale. We left at 5AM from Haputale for the sunrise at 6AM but that was a bit short because the entrance was still closed so our taxi stopped us there which is 1,4km before the summit. So at 6AM we were halfway up from the entrance to the summit and we actually found the perfect spot to watch the sunrise :) we then finished the climb up to the Lipton Seat and finally went back all the way down to the tea factory while walking through the tea plantations. The sunrise, the view from the top but, even more, the tea plantation landscape all around us on the way down was absolutely gorgeous! Then it was super easy to find a tuktuk driver at the tea factory to get us back to Haputale. A must do!

we traveled here from Haputhale. last seven kilometers we took a three wheeler which cost 1000LKR. that way we can enjoy the surrounding and get rid of the stress associated with driving your own vehicle in a narrow road.

A must do, knowing how tea is being made is great. It helped and leaned me also a lot about what influences government, shareholders and in the end customers have on local circumstances. It did not change for the better, and other tea sites are really a lot worse off. A pity big companies are watched through western eyes only.

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. We visited Liptons Seat during a daytrip with a minivan. The road on the tea estate (where you have to pay for entering) was very bad, but the vista's on the teafields were great! When we reached Liptons Seat it turned oud to be a polyester statue-bench under an ugly sort of steel and concrete parasol.
This region of Sri Lanka is absolutely stunning. I cannot recommend a walk thru these mountains highly enough. Grab a guide if you can and even g a bit further into the high mountain villages..

The scenery is wonderful.  Well worth the trip.  However the tuk-tuks that go all the way to the top ruin the peaceful countryside.  Make sure you stop at the gate (where they charge 100 RP per person) and walk the last part of the road to truly enjoy this magical place.

Staying in Ella and decided to do trip up to Lipton‚Äôs Seat. It‚Äôs a good 1.5 hour drive up mountain twisty roads to get there so bear that in mind if you want to go. Not a great route if you get car sick. Driver suggested we leave at 5.30-6 am in order to get there and make assent before mist rolled in and obscured the views. However, we are not early risers (family with teenagers!) and we hate missing our nice hotel breakfasts (a packed one is never the same!) especially when you pay a premium to stay somewhere. We were staying at 98 Acres and views from the restaurant there are amazing in themselves and probably the best breakfast we‚Äôve had on our trip to Sri Lanka to date so not to be missed! We ended up leaving hotel around 9.30 and got up to the tea factory around 11.15. We then opted to take the rest of the route by tuk tuk. We needed 2 and they were SLR1000 each for the round trip. I did a bit of research beforehand and the average price is somewhere between 800-1500 rupees for a return tuk tuk depending on your negotiating skills and how busy it is. Some people were walking up but my guess is it would take you 45-60 mins to walk up. It‚Äôs not a difficult walk, you just follow the road as it winds up the mountain. Tuk tuk was much more fun though! It took about 15-20 mins to get to the top. It was a great way to make the assent and look out at the landscape and beautiful views. Once near the top you need to lay a further fee at a gate of 100 rupees per person to go right to the top. I‚Äôm sure the views are great but it was heavy with mist at the top, we couldn‚Äôt see much if the views. It was still nice up there though and we had a cup of tea and a few snacks that were brought out by a few plantation workers whilst we were up there (tbh I wasn‚Äôt keen on drinking or eating anything due to hygiene but we thought we should  just go with it.....I‚Äôm glad we did as in end it was only 400 rupees and it doesn‚Äôt really matter if you drink or eat any of it). The best thing about the trip was the fun tuk tuk ride which the kids loved. It doesn‚Äôt matter what time of the day you go for that, but if you‚Äôre desperate for views the go early. The most interesting ting for me was seeing the workers village and the tea plantation itself, and that‚Äôs all around where you pick up the tuk tuk to go up to the top viewing point.

the roads are narrow and wind through the tea estate. you'll see tea pickers busily pluck away and maybe smile at a nosy tourist every now and then. As you go higher, the views are breathtaking. We went up in a small car, so it was perfect. especially the roads are very narrow at the top with hardly any parking. I really think the tourisim department needs to develop this a lot further, as the place on top could use better management. but the view. that's what you really go there for.
It's really cold and windy at the top view point, which i love. The view is breath taking. the tea or coffee with hot short eats from the small shop at the top is a welcom treat!!

On of the picturesque view points in Sri Lanka. No wonder why Lipton himself chose the place according to folklore. You can see quite a distance from here with number of districts and provinces. Given a holiday you happen to visit I rather advise anyone to take a tuk tuk from the tea factory upwards. Because it could be a night marish to pass 2 vehicles by since the road is very narrow. But you might have to negotiate with the provider for a better price. Must visit place for nature lovers and photographers.

Tuk tuk ride from haputale to Lipton seat paid 800 roupies (only 1 way) to a driver met in the street the day before (my guesthouse proposed me 1500 roupies for the same service...). Arrived at the top around 7:30 am. Very clear view that changed dramatically in 10 minutes time, around 7:40. The views are actually the best from a curve on the road 5min walk before Lipton seat. Nice to walk back down across the tea plantations. Very few tourists when I was there. At Lipton seat, child trying to get money or food...

One of the most amazing walks i had in my life and I believe it will be always the best one! Unforgettable views all the way down from Lipton‚Äôs seat, don‚Äôt take TukTuk when you are going down, just enjoy the tea plantation and talk to the tea planters . For the view on Lipton‚Äôs seat, sadly i arrived at 9:30 so the view was not clear however i love Lipton üòÇ so i was happy to take photos there. The experience itself is absolutely amazing !

Plan your visit before 10AM to reach there. Because after that mist might cover the view. Amazing view at the top of the mountains. Best part is drive through to the top inside the tea estates. Amazing drive through as its green all over. We drove through in car but the roads are too narrow so recommend to take tuk tuk from down the tea factory to Lipton seat top. Spend quality time up as the view is amazing.

I would recommend to go there early morning for the sunrise. You can combine it with some tea, fresh rotti with sambol and a great view at the top. And when you feel like hiking, walk your way down. It was one of the best sunrises I've ever seen.
Try to get there before the mist comes in, say 10 am. Don‚Äôt follow the road unless you have to and look for the short cuts that the tea pickers use to get around

I took tuk tuk from Ella to get to Lipton seat - was 1,5 hours ride but when you get there you totally rewarded !!! The view and the scenery are absolutely phenomenal - you literally can touch the clouds. There is a small simple cafe serving some tea and roti , just in case you need a bite before heading back.
Tour the tea factory then take a tuk tuk (800-1000 rupees rt) up to to enjoy a panoramic view of the gorgeous tea country.
A rough road up to the place from Haputhale Town passing Dambetenna Tea Factory. However worthy visit to have a great view of Tea Plantations 360¬∞

We visited Lipton‚Äôs Seat on a day trip on a scooter from Ella. The drive to get to Lipton‚Äôs Seat is what was the most amazing for us as we had left it too late and it was cloudy by the time we arrived at the top. The drive up the windy road through the tea fields was just amazing. We were cheered on by local school kids and saw the women in the fields picking the tea. We arrived at Lipton's seat around lunchtime the tea pickers were having their break and congregating at the view point. They asked if we wanted to take their picture for a fee. We declined. We were disappointed with ourselves for forgetting to take biros/pens with us as loads of the kids were asking for school pens. Lipton's Seat is ticketed and you have to pay per person and vehicle to access the view point. There is a local cafe at the top. Beware that at the moment there are construction works at the seat where he is sat. Top tip: Get there at sunrise to get clear views! We didn't ask if there were or used toilets.

We took a tuk tuk up to Lipton's Seat at around 8:30am on a relatively nice day.  The views at the top were ok but not spectacular - it might have been better to arrive a little earlier.  What was very beautiful was the walk back down as we could see people picking the tea leaves and were surrounded by beautiful green scenery in every direction. As we got closer to the bottom we could see the fog/clouds rolling in so we were lucky we got there relatively early. The Dambatenne Tea Factory tour at the bottom was a complete was of time - uninterested guide who was clearly more interesting in trying to sell the tea than anything else.

Lipton‚Äôs seat itself is hit or miss as there can often be mist or clouds blocking the view from the top...but walking through the tea plantations either to or from Lipton‚Äôs seat is spectacular! Don‚Äôt miss the beauty and fun of the journey.

Our driver took us up to the entrance to Lipton Seat. You have to walk another 1.4km up the hill. It's a good hike but you can negotiate a tuk tuk. Try paying 300 for the lift up, wait and then lift back. It's worth it. The walk down to the tea factory is long, but also worth it.

Lipton's seat in off Haputale, about 22 kms. Accessible by private or public transport. Public transport available upto Dambetenne Tea Factory where its advisable to leave even a private vehicle there as the estate road is too narrow for two vehicles to pass. Best is to either on foot or by taking a tuk tuk from there for around Rs. 800 both ways. We found a nice guy called Siva who was a very friendly person from whom we got much information. The tea estate seems to have an extent of about 3300 hectares. The view all the way up was fantastic and scary too at moments. Lucky to be there when it was clear and clouds started rolling in when leaving covering up the views. Best is to travel there as early as possible. The tea shop up there serves fine tea.
A lot of fog even though we made it up there early. Don‚Äôt take a tuktuk all the way up, walk from the tea factory (2h up, same down). If you ride, you‚Äôll miss the best part of the landscape.

We hired a scooter and went from Ella. Have to be confident to drive though and nerves of steel lol. If not hire a tuk tuk from Haputale. The views on the way up are fantastic and so worth the drive. We got to the top a bit late so it had clouded over on one side. Had a cuppa and a snack at the top before we ventured back down. Had a chat with some of the locals and really enjoyed üòÅ

From Haputale i caught the bus 9 kms  to Dambatenne  where the bus stops and returns to town. However there is another smaller bus that takes you much further towards Lipton's Seat, but i decided to hike the last 8 kms up the hill. I walked through the village of Dambatenne and the road led uphill for the next 5 kms, sometimes quite steep. Eventually i crossed a ridge and the road leveled out until it reached the ticket office where i purchased an entrance ticket for Lipton's Seat. The last kilometer was all uphill. There were a few other people there and there was a statue of Lipton, himself sitting on a bench (where most of the visitors sat with him for a photo). The view was quite good and on a clear day you could see the coastline. This is where Sir Lipton used to come and sit. I decided to walk back all the way to Haputale (16kms) and it was well worth doing.

We got a tuk-tuk from Haputale to the tea factory and did the walk up to the top. Even though it was walking on the road it was brilliant. We started at 7.30am as we heard that the later you leave it, the greater the chance the clouds will have rolled in. We enjoyed every bit of the climb up and it is not too taxing. The local teapickers were making their way to work as we ascended and later we saw them at work. You are surrounded by  tea from the minute you start to the minute you reach the top. The view from the top was amazing (even though a little hazy). Only negative point was the rather expensive cup of tea at the top (by Sri Lankan standards) but we had to have some!!

From Haputale, we took tuk-tuk at 5 mp to get there for a sunrise and we were very happy with the decision. Don't go to the very top where the Lipton is seated, stay about 300 m below where the road curves and enjoy the splendid view of the valley. Take a tripod for better pictures! The way down is very easy and enjoyable 7km long walk, but it feels much shorter. You can observe ladies picking tea leaves, they are very sweet and even keen to pose you! Take some pens and other school supplies as you will meet many local kids.

Lipton‚Äôs Seat was great and never-to-be-forgotten trip, starting from the drive through the tea estates and finally to the view point. View from the point is out of the world feel..! Best time to get seeable view is between 11am-3.30pm after that clouds/fog commands the place.

Certain worth it, we took a tuk tuk (recently done Adams Peak and didn't fancy the trek!) up and down and stopped at various breath taking view points on the way. Recommend doing it as early as possible in the day to get the best views before the cloud rolls in. The tea at the top is both cheap and best way to relax and enjoy the scenery!

You can arrive by bus to Dambatenne factory or take a tuk-tuk to the top at Lipton's seat. We recommend taking the short cuts to be immersed in the nature and say hello to the tea pickers. We also went through the Tamil villages and saw the lovely kids coming back from school. We don't recommend to visit Dambatenne factory though. 250 Rs and not even a tasting experience.

What a tuk-tuk ride! A convey of tuk-tuk snake their way up the mountain to the penultimate view of Sri Lanka. Ask your hotel to book Safran. He'll give you a hoot of a tour with plenty of honks to boot- he seems to know everyone in Haputale.

We skipped the factory as we had only just been to another one. We did use the wash room which cost 20 rupee each, not sure what the money went towards as they were horrific. We then took a tuk tuk to meet Mr Lipton. When we arrived it was misty but it soon cleared. The views and the journey were spectacular. We had tea and rotti at the top. Food was delicious but the workers were trying to get as much money out of you as possible by giving you more without asking

At first we wanted to take a walk to Lipton's Seat, but our driver arranged a couple of tuk tuks to take us up hill. From the last village to the seat wouldn't have been too much to walk, but we got the tuk tuks from far away, so it seemed like too much to walk. The guys were nice enough to stop at every nice view in order for us to take pictures. The view was amazing all the way up. Sadly when we got to the chair, there was a lot of mist on one side of the cliff and we couldn't admire everything, but the view that we had was amazing!

The highest point in the area with distant views of five of the provinces of Sri Lanka. We were told that on a clear day one can see the ocean from here.  It was a little too hazy when we were up there.

The location was perfect..wonderful place and excellent customer service. .come enjoy and enjoy it..price is good. .very friendly owners. .The accommodation is basic but very clean.great value for money............

This is great  place.they are very friendly .super food.super peoples.we had three days there ..there serviceis best to best.we will coe back this place again.i am recommend  this place ..thankyou for your best services .

The walk up from the entrance gate is about 1.3 km according to my tuktuk driver. It took a very leisurely hour, stopping to take pictures and marvel at misty mountain views and ghostly tree silhouettes. Walk it if you have two legs, it's worth it. The trail itself is glorious and at the top you can get some nice strong hot tea and/or coconut roti and wadi. I walked the 8km down but loved wandering through the terraces so much it was more like 15. I would totally recommend spending an entire morning, if not day, doing just that. The people are super sweet and will even invite you into their house for tea. Take 'school pens' or stickers along to give the children living there, it makes them so excited! You can grab the bus back to Haputale for 16 rupees.

Wonderful views, fascinating tea production and tea pickers The view from Lipton‚Äôs seat is incredible and well worth a visit Unfortunately if you are a dog lover the state of the many stray dogs in this area is very distressing and could spoil your visit as mange is horrendous

After the tea factory tour we took a tuk tuk up the hair bend road to the gate of Liptons Seat. The drive was exhilarating and our driver was great - safe, careful and happy to chat & point things out. He was more than happy to stop for photos and taking in the view. Once we got to the gate the road was closed to vehicles as they were resurfacing it. So we happily got out and walked the last 1.5km up the road and I'm glad we had to. The walk was really enjoyable and it felt better to be strolling through the quiet tea plantation up to the summit. Once at the top the view was magnificent and well worth the climb - it felt like we were on top of the world. You could have a cup of tea up there in the ramshackle cafe if you wished. We walked back down to the gate then we drove back down to the tea factory and thoroughly enjoyed the experience for the princely sum of 800/- A real bargain.

I started from Ella with a train to Haputale. From there I took the bus to the Tea factory. I can't understand why people take the journey to the top with a tuktuk or a minivan. The hike through the tea plantations was exhausting but totally worth it. The liptons seat itself is quite nice, but not that special (to many people, to many tuktuks)

Lipton's seat is situated in the Hill country East of Haputale. The views on a clear day from the top are absolutely stunning beautiful. It is possible to walk or take a Tuktuk. We enjoyed very much the views and a nice cup of tea from the small friendly restaurant at the top. Well worth a visit.
Fantastic experience with great views. Lovely walk through the tea plantations to get there, but you can also hire a tuk-tuk.

We enjoyed visiting Lipton‚Äôs Seat. The area has great views of lovely tea plantations and a lot of history. You can get nice tea and breakfast at the little restaurant next to Lipton‚Äôs Seat. Don‚Äôt pay more than 50 rupees for a cup of tea

Don't go unless it's a perfectly clear day - which you can't guarantee. To get here takes a very, very long, uncomfortable, winding drive along very poor roads - our driver got stuck several times. There had been a lot of hype so we were very excited about this stop...what a massive disappointment!! The weather was poor so when we finally reached the top all we could see was cloud. Added to that, the promise of refreshment at the top was met by a tiny shack selling only local tea (incredibly sweet) and snacks (exceptionally spicy) with questionable hygiene - fine if you are a backpacker perhaps, but with two small children in tow this was a depressing and stressful end to a very tough day of travelling...with only the promise of the same horrible journey back down. Not worth it.

I went to many attractions in Sri Lanka, but this was exceptional. One of my top things to have done in Sri Lanka. I got a tuktuk from the tea factory, and the ride up the mountain is great fun by itself, with plenty of photo opportunities of tea pickers and their homes. And when you reach the top, the view is stunning. I was told it can vary with mist and cloud, but it was fine the morning we were there (around 11am). I rank this so highly, as it is accessible to anyone who can get in a tuktuk, the ride is an experience, and it is such a spectacular view at the top.

You need to brave the long winding ride of about 8km up the tea slopes. If you manage to reach the top the views are stunning. Other than that there really isn't much else about this place. A bit ambivalent regarding whether it was really worth the effort. But all in all if you are near the Haputale area, I think you should consider giving this place a visit.

Beautiful view. We took shortcuts thru the tea bushes. but be very careful it's slippery. There a small caf√© run by the locals. Wade, Rotti, fish cutlets and black tea are available. Food items are a bit overpriced. But worth going there for the view. Go early as possible.

On our trip to the Uva region, which we allocated about 2.5 days, Lipton‚Äôs Seat was one of the few things we had planned for and we are glad we did. Lipton‚Äôs Seat has tremendous views of the surrounding tea plantations. I recommend going early in the morning (7am to 10am) as that‚Äôs when it‚Äôs most clear. We had a driver take us up as the walk is quite long (5.5km+). If a driver is not an option, a tuk tuk can take you up. Beyond the views, keep an eye out for the local plantation workers - a true indication of the region‚Äôs culture and economic livelihood.
After about one hour journey i reached to the place. At that time full of misty in afternoon. But after certain time i could see the view. It was very beautiful. Good place for nature lover.

We had arranged to be picked-up at our hotel by tuktuk at 5.30 h in the morning, so that we could experience the sunrise at Lipton's Seat.  It's an approx. 29 kilometres tuktuk ride.  Truly spectacular up there.  It was so peaceful and quiet!   But do it early in the morning, as the daily clouds will start rolling-in later in the morning, blocking the fantastic mountain views from this hill top.  Tea and a snack can be served at the top.  It can be chilly early in the morning, dress well.  It's absolutely worth getting up for this early in the morning!!  Around the hill-top, just stroll down a bit along the road, amids the tea plantations.

The only place you can see five districts and sea in one time. This is lovely viewpoint that locate in top of the mount range. you can buy some snacks from there.There were very cool climate on that day. But the road is not comfortable.

The best view over the tea plantations. You can take the care halfway up.Walk the rest or take a tuk-tuk (300 Rds). Be amazed by the magnificent views over the tea plantations. Views are even better than on Worlds End. And you can drive there. Enjoy the ride through the fields and take your time to soak in the views. It is the best view point we visited in Sri Lanka. You might feel like you are on top of the world.
You can walk up to Liptons seat, but we took a tuktuk both ways and were glad we did seeing a number of very hot and bothered people struggling up the very steep hills!

With or without a thick covering of mist, the view of tea-covered hills is worth the long drive along at times quite narrow roads. Some enterprising people have set up a tea kiosk at the top where you can also get snacks.

Can drive all the way to the top or there is a bus from Haputale town to Dambetenna tea factory. From there can either take a tuk tuk to the top or hike to the top. Need to take an entrance ticket to reach the top of the hill. The view from the top is spectacular. Now there is a little tea shop at the top selling hot tea and yummy roti.

This is a must visit viewpoint on top of a lovely mountain range, where you can see miles and miles of land towards the sea side and towards the inland mountains. You can also see a series of reservoirs in SL, where some are contributing to hydroelectric power generation. Better to visit during the morning half of the day. Closest town is Haputale so probably you can find a nice cozy hotel there. From Haputale town you need to travel like 15 km uphill on a very narrow windy and misty road. Make sure you are ready for some real driving action. Almost all the journey two vehicles cannot pass each other so if you meet a vehicle coming downhill get ready to reverse one heck of a reverse. But if you love driving its all good or get a well experienced driver. After facing all these roadside obstacles, once you reach to the peak, the view will sure calm you down. Its breathtaking. Totally worth the drive.

Great drive up to Lipton Seat through tea plantations and past tea factories. However it was very misty and damp at the top with no view at all. Also no toilet and a very basic 'cafe'. We waited two hours with no sign of the view appearing before returning to Haputale. Our only miss in an otherwise terrific trip to Sri Lanka.

Definitely worth a look. Fun Tuk Tuk ride up from the tea factory. Great photo opportunities on the way. Early is the best time but be prepared for mist at the top. It does break and the view is wonderful.

We made an excursion to visit the tea plantation from Ella (train to Hapatule, bus to Dambutenne) - it's easy without a guide. Well-worth it, but advise you to leave early (for best chance at getting good view at top, and to miss the hot afternoon sun). We just made it to the top in time to get a decent view before the fog closed in, but we had to tuk-tuk up to the gate. Unless you're starting from Hapatule in the early morning I would recommend the tuk-tuk up and walk down (the walk down is plenty to take in the magnificent and tranquil scenery of the plantation - and the walk up could be tough in the heat unless reasonably fit). Highly recommended (even if you don't get good views at the top; the highlight is walking through the tea fields - the view at the seat is just a bonus). Remember to take small change (I think it was 100Rs each for entry at the gate) - we forgot to take enough to cover the tuk-tuk as well and had difficulty exchanging a 5000 note...
Stunning drive through steep tea gardens to reach this stunning viewpoint, especially that to the South. Could be the objective of excellent hikes also.  Nice simple cafe nearby.
