Our group of four 50+ women decided to walk up to Liptons Seat from Dambatenne tea factory. Despite many tuk tuk drivers telling us it was very steep and far, we wanted to slowly take in the sights. It was a 2 hour walk up a gently winding road through glorious tea plantations. The views were sublime and we loved seeing the workers and tea pickers going through their daily tasks en route. Unfortunately it was clouded in at the top at Liptons seat. In hindsight we should have taken tuk tuk up to top early and then just walked down while still clear. But despite that we all loved this walk.

Great place to see nice views of the area. Do it on sunrise! It is definitely worth the early hours. Tuk tuk should cost around 1000 lkr. It is 45 min drive ftom Haputale. There is a nice spot to shoot the sunrise around 5 min walk before you get to the seat.
Dont go to the bar they are dishonest. The view is nice but skip the bar they charge a lot for tea skip them.

We visited all the landmarks placed under Mr. Thomas J. Liptons seat like Dambetenne tea planations and factory but this place makes it worth. We took a tuktuk from Ella and he was with us whole trip, stopped for pictures and waited everytime we went for a walk. With the way back it cost us 4200 Rp. The entry fee is 100 Rp. for a person and 50 Rp. fot a vehicle if you are lazy to walk up the hill ( as we were). The statue of Mr. Lipton is made from plastic but...you know...Sri Lanka style. Up there is a small cabin that offers a tea and breakfast (we arrived around 9:00 a.m.) but it lookd like it‚Äôs a gift. It is not.

We weren't lucky.  You can allegedly see multiple provinces, we saw a wall of fog.  Our guide didn't tell us to get there early, so it was a long ride for nothing.  When you are driving around tea country in Sri Lanka you will see miles and miles of beautiful views and overlooks.  Not sure this is worth the time.

We had a brilliant Saturday out in Haputale. Got the 9.30am train down from Galle (100 rupees for two tickets, which you can buy on the day). It took an hour and the scenery was amazing. Wandered around Haputale for a while then got a tuk tuk up to Addisham Monastery, Dambatenne tea factory and Lipton's seat. (2500 rupees round trip). The tuk tuk rude was amazing in itself, along winding roads with astonishing views. The beautiful looking monastery was a quick visit (only open at weekends), tea factory tour was short and interesting (not open Sundays), and the view from Lipton seat brilliant. Got a 'high season' special 3.45pm train back to Galle. Highly recommended day.

Lipton‚Äôs Seat is the famous viewpoint where Sir Thomas Lipton used to sit and contemplate his plantation with its stony landscape and green tea bushes. Located in misty Haputale, on your way to Dambethenna Estate. Once you are at the summit, to say the view is spectacular would be an understatement. The climb is worth it, just for this. How to get here Take the signed narrow paved road from the Dambetenna tea factory and climb about 7km through lush tea plantations to the lookout. From the tea factory, the ascent should take about 2¬Ω hours. The earliest bus leaves Haputale at 6.30am. You will enjoy the talk with tea pluckers going off to work as you walk uphill to Lipton‚Äôs Seat. Alternatively, you can hire a tuk-tuk from the viewpoint too. but recommend the walk to get the full use of your journey.

Took the tuk tuk from Olive Hilltop Hotel and reached Lipton's seat to see the sunrise. There is a tea shop, DON'T DRINK that tea, its horrible. Other than that, its a good experience. It gets very windy, so make sure you have warm clothes. Walk back to the Tea Factory where you can get a bus back to Haputale (LKR 50, if i remember correctly.... which is roughly $0.35). There are TOILETS on the way down but NOT AT Lipton's seat, you have to pay like LKR 20. The tea factory has a small tour for LKR 300/$2 (maybe more, don't remember exact amount) but we didn't take the tour as we have seen similar things before.
If you go early this trip offers wonderful views. We left Haputale around 5:30AM and took a tuktuk to the top, enjoyed the view and walked back to Haputale.

The trip to Lipton's started with an inspection of the tea factory which was interesting. We then proceeded to Lipton's seat. We enjoyed the vista and then walked had way down the mountain! We will fondly remember that trip!

"We took the local bus from Haputale to Dambatenne tea factory for 80 rupees but they can take you by bus straight to Lipton's seat. We walked from the factory 7 km up to the hill, the walk is beautiful, surrounded by small willages and tea plantations. Be aware that weather can change rapidly and be ready for a cloud burst. The view is amazing from the seat if not foggy. You can get a pot of tea in a kind of restaurant teher for 350 ruppes.

A beautiful place with incredible views across south Sri Lanka.  The view is best at sunrise, which is also the time where Lipton's Seat and the view is least likely to be covered in cloud. We started the walk at 5.30am and reached the top about 6.00am. Take something warm to wear. There is a cafe at the top that opens around this time, it serves great tea and fresh roti and other breakfast food. It's worth a visit for breakfast. They will keep bringing you food until you say stop!

We left our B&B in Haputale at 5am and took a tuktuk to Lipton's seat. You have to walk the last 1km or so but it was a gentle hill on a paved road. We had great views of the sunrise and surrounding tea plantations - made it worth getting up early. We also had a quick breakfast at the caf√© at the top - tea, roti and other snacks. It was 50Rs per item and they will bring food until you say stop, it was all very tasty.

One of amazing place to have wonderful views. Approx 12km from haputhale town. Better if you can visit there by safari jeep or buddy lorry. Had unforgettable journey to lipton seat. You can see n feel the beauty of the nature. Please visit before 12 noon to have better view if not mist will be the everything you can see there. Shortcut off road available from entrace gate to top of the mountain thro the tea state if you can climb.

Perfect half day trip! Just go up by tuk tuk and then walk down approx. 8 kilometres down to the tea factory. Even if we were up at Lipton's Seat quite early, there were clouds, so no view... But nonetheless, it was worth to go there, since the scenery is beautiful and it is so nice to walk down through the tea plantation. Even our teenage kids liked it; not only the selfies with the Sir Lipton statue...!

The view at this point is amazing!! It is really beautiful to walk back from this point in the direction of the Dambatenne Tea Factory (if this is too far for you, you can aks a tuk tuk driver to pick you up halfway).

This is a must go attraction if you are in Haputale. Due to mist we couldn't see much but as i heard from locals that doesnt happen often. If you are in this area make sure to go there before 5 am to watch the sunrise. If you are travelling by your own vehicle a quick advice i would like to give to others is that they need to keep their vehicles near dabethanna team factory and take a tuk tuk from their. Reason behind this is that the road is soo small for two vehicles and some times you might need to reverse 300m to find a spot for the other vehicle to cross.
Had a lovely day there. Ou must go early morning to see the sunrise. Had a blast there. Also need to be careful cuz hornets. One shop on the to with amazing view.
If you are travelling to Haputale visit Lipton seat you can see a lovely view.Heard that if we come at 5.30 in the morning we can see the sun rise too before coming to the top point.

This is an amazing place that you can see some amazing landscaping of the Country. You need to be there as early as possible to see the entire aria as if you get late the clouds will cover the entire view. It's about 30-45 minutes drive by a car (slow drive) You will have a small shop which serve tea, Roti, Wadai which you can buy for cheap.

Just going up to Lipton's seat will bring you through amazing green tea plantations. This itself is already definitely worth going up there. Going to Lipton's seat you need to get there early, as it will become misty in the afternoon. On top there is a small place where they provide you tea and some Sri Lankan snacks, which is quite nice. I don't know what they base the bill on, but expect to pay somewhere between 600 and 800 LKR.

We went at Lipton's seat at 11 am ad it was already too late because the weather was cloudy. The entrance is 50 LKR p.p. + 100 LKR if you come with a tuktuk. Even with clouds, the landscape is amazing. In my opinion, the best tea plantations I saw in Sri Lanka.

Lipton's seat was amazing ! We climbed all the way up (about 2hrs walk), quite strenuous but completely worth it when you get to the top. The view is amazing (we went around sunset time) and the surroundings are pittoresque. This is definitely an unmissable walk

We, like most people went by a tuk tuk to Liptons Seat. The trouble was when we got to the entry gate where you pay for your ticket the tuk tuk driver let us out. We thought we were there but there was another 1 and a half km walk up steep hillside to get to the viewpoint. We had not been well and this was the last thing we needed. We met other people who had been cheated by tuk tuk drivers in the same way. By the time we got to the top the fog had closed in and there was no view. Others said it had been clear 10 mins earlier . This was at 8.30am so go early. The statue is of fibreglass, not bronze. The surrounding tea plantation scenery is worth the trip.

You can arrange a tuk tuk at the city centre the day before to pick you up at your hotel the next morning for a ride up to Lipton's Seat to watch the sun rise. There will be others there but it was not too crowded.

Get a feeling for tea, by making this tour. I would recommend to go up by TukTuk and to walk back down.  I would recommend an early tour in order to avoid to see the mist. The area is sensitve to quickly changin weather conditions. Would also recommend to take the short cuts by walking straight downhill through the tea fields.

I think the road to get there is almost as great as the view itself. Indeed, you will drive across many tea plantings and the road is impressive with some great views in between. Once there you can enjoy the view if it is not fogy. I really recommend it, but you will need some time to drive there and so you should plan some hours to do this place.
Outstanding panoramic view and great 2 hours walk back to the tea factory among the tea plantations with beautiful lively green colours and tamil women pickers.

I took a tuktuk as it is a really long and sometimes steep walk. Really enjoyable and tranquil trip... I should even have gone earlier than the official sunrise... to get the most of the superb early morning light. But... surprise, Sir Lipton is not made of bronze but of fiberglass, superbly painted with a nice patina ;-) I hope he will be repaired soon as some *** broke off the famous cup of Lipton tea ;-(. Up there a friendly team even offers a big SL breakfast, a pot of tea or hot food at nice prices. A small fee is asked to pass through the well kept Dambetenna tea plantations. Lots to see on the way - including everyday life of the Tamil tea pickers.
360 Views across hills, tea plantations and a good walk down to the tea factory below. There is a little cafe right at the top serving team and pastries. Well worth the climb (or drive up).

If you're wondering whether the rather long (1 hour) scooter drive from Ella to Lipton's Seat is worth it: it totally is! It's one of those things where the ride is even more beautiful than the destination. Driving by acres of tea plantations actively being worked gives amazing scenery, and along the way there's a tea factory you van visit with a guide for a cheap price (thinking about 200 Rs p.p.). Tip: don't go on a Monday, as the factory isn't operational then (no harvest on Sundays). You can still visit the factory though.

Many years ago I went to World's End, but after having been there I should say that instead you better go to Lipton Seat, because the views are quite similar and the last part of the road leading to Lipton's Seat, between Dambatenna  Tea Factory and the summit is stunning! It's like one giant beautiful tea garden with numerous picturesque spots. Villages of Tamil tea pickers and tea factory staff are scattered around on the mountain slopes. I was lucky to be there on a sunny day and I fully enjoyed every minute over there. Although the view from Lipton's favourable seat is spectacular, I was more impressed riding on my scooter through the tea plantations. Undoubtedly one of my favourite spots in the upcountry. There is a regular public bus service from Bandarawela, as well as from Haputale to Ambantenna Tea Factory. From there you can take a tuktuk to the Lipton Seat and walk back to the tea factory to catch the bus back. On the summit is a small local cafe serving soft drinks, juices, tea and snacks. Go there in the morning; it gets more cloudy in due of the day.

We took a tuk tuk one way to get up to Lipton's Seat for sunrise - we were not disappointed with the early morning rise! We had the whole place to ourselves and it was magical watching the sun rise over the tea plantations. Be sure to pack some decent warmies as it was very chilly and windy. We had a fantastic, warming breakfast up at the cafe overlooking what Sir Lipton would've back in the day. With full bellies, we walked down to Dambutene Tea Factory which was a nice gentle stroll down and through the tea fields in the rain üòÑ (approx. 1.5 - 2 hours down).

The view from Lipton seat is absolutely breathtaking with mountains on one side and the tea estates on the other. You definitely need to spend some time here taking it all in and trying to capture a fraction of the beauty with your camera. It does get chilly here so make sure to dress appropriately. The food offered by the small shack on top is overpriced and probably not the best tea or food you've had, but the family's hospitality and warmth may win you over and make it all worthwhile! If you're up for it, you can hike down to Dambatanne tea factory from Lipton seat which is about 7kms and allows you to walk by and potentially explore some of the smaller villages. You may also be greeted by some of the tea pickers on their way to work and local children on their way to school!
probably one of the most beautiful places in sri lanka.long very beautiful path to a heavenly place..
Must visit place in Sri Lanka of Nature Lovers. People who are like walk with cool climate no 1 place in Sri Lanka.

We arrived on the Lipton's Seat after lunch, which was too late and the view was already covered in clouds. However, we were able to admire the view on the other side - on the tea plantation, which was absolutely worth it too.

The view from Liptons seat really is impressive. We decided to hire a driver to take us there from the center of Haputale as i suffer from vertigo and was unsure id make the climb. Most of the road is through the tea plantations although certain parts are a little on the edge, however travelling before dawn meant i couldn't see the drops! The top is really safe and there is even a small cafe although we didn't go in. We then walked back down through the tea  plantation which is a real pleasure.

Amazing place and if you go there you may see 6 Districts if there is no fog. Try to go there early morning and amazing weather climate as well. If you take tuk tuk from Haputhale Railway station just 1200LKR with return. Don't forget to have a tea with pol Roti for that place shop and kind peoples.

We went a bit further up the hills to visit Lipton's seat after seeing the Dembele tea factory. There is a lovely collection of chairs and tables where you can buy snacks and tea. The view is well worth climbing the steep hills to reach.

We rented a little scooter and made our way up in the morning. The view along the way is absolutely stunning and peaceful. At the top you can have a cup of tea and snacks watching an amazing view. Also you can visit a tea factory on the way down. Absolutely worth the visit! My girlfriend and I actually went there again on our way back to Colombo, just a few days after!

This place is very much popular because of Sir James Lipton. He is the one who changed the tea industry in Sri Lanka and put Ceylon in the global tea industry. It was between 7km walk from Dambetanna tea factory. You can get a three wheeler if you are not a fan of hiking. It would cost you $10. The ride is between the misty tea estate. Walking there is like you are waling among the clouds. If you are lucky enough you can see five provinces there with Udawalawa tank, Handapanagala tank and Chandrika tank. There is a good tea spot there. Go and enjoy. They have nice pol roti, wade and nice ginger tea. We recommend to have a walk. The view and ambience is astounding and refreshing.
A place where a person should visit. If anyone would like to visit make sure that you visit the place before 9am after that the road get jammed and you can't reach to the top.

The only location in Sri Lanka where 5 Provinces can be seen. On a clear day, the sea is visible from the Hambantota side and the Mattala Airport. Also on another day Adams peak is visible. Place founded by Charles Lipton. Now it is been ran by a plantation company. Roads leading up to the place is narrow. A 4x4 ideal however having a small vehicle is also fine. A place which is a must see. Go ask for Narayan, a good character with local knowledge

This is a must go tour in Haputale area. Very nice trip through plantations. Do NOT go from Bandarawela, because road is not good and you will find additional toll gate. Start from Haputale, so trip is easy. From the top, you can see five districts (when no mist) namely, Monaragala, Batticaloa, Hambantota, Badulla, Rathnapura. Never forget to take a good binocular here, so in a good day, you can see Batticaloa sea.
Stunning views, picture perfect drive, awesome weather and wonderful scenaries of lively-hood amidst the beautiful tea trees.

We were staying at White Monkey - Dias rest, around 12km from lipton's seat (4km out from Haputale town). Some of the other guests advised we take a tuktuk or a car up to Lipton's seat, as the walk would be too long and strenuous. However, we had our hearts set on the walk - the pivotal reason we were visiting Haputale - and so decided to hike up the next morning anyway. We left the guesthouse around 6am and had a beautiful two and a half hour hike to Lipton's seat. We passed a small lake, walked through cloud forest and past lush tea plantations. There are signs along the way with words of wisdom about environmental issues and protecting the planet as well as a count down towards lipton's seat. The views going up were different to any that we have ever encountered and it has been our favourite hike in Sri Lanka so far. The walk can be strenuous at times, but it is mainly a gradual incline on a good path with plenty of places to rest or get snacks or water. At the top we were greeted with tea, toffee, rotti and corn cakes: so delicious and just what we fancied after the hike. The views are stunning, however the mist and clouds surround the view point from around 8:30am onwards, so try aim to be there before. At the top you can get a tuktuk back down, or walk to the tea factory where there are plenty more tuktuks willing to take you back into town.

get a tuck tuck to drive you up to the top of the hill where lucky ones will see breathtaking views of the estate. If fog is surrounding just get a tea and enjoy the warmth of the cup. Walk back to the estate if weather allows it. Tour of factory is basic but nice anyway.

It's one of the most impressive places in all respects The way to get there best by tuktuk from Haputale and do stop as the views on this long drive are fascinating but so are the tea plucked villages and you have many opportunities to see them close and experience theyre friendly contacts Visit also the Hindu temple and the people in the enclosed village around it the top is an ultimate view place in all directions but mainly to the south and west so go there early as it can get misty from noon and then the famous view has gone If you are good in walking do it from the entrance port it's a great walk and visit the shady cafe for lunch or?whatever you need

It is a long climb to this place. We did it on a scooter which was perfect for us. Don't try to do the walk from Haputale but arrange a drop off nearer to Lipton Seat. The place itself is bare but offers a drink and snack, but no toilets also not on the way.

We could see panoramic views all around.  The day we went was cloudy.  Because of that we couldn't see all the way to the southern coastline.  But according to people who live around there a person can see the southern coast. Walking up to the observation point from the gate was a good exercise and it was pleasant walk because the road was between tea grown areas.

Took the 6.40 AM train out of Ella and was in Haputhale about an hour later. Took a tuk tuk from the train station for Rs 1000. Dropped off at the entrance where we paid Rs 50 and walked the rest of the way up to Liptons Seat. Wasn't very misty so the view was pretty great. We then walked back down all the way to the Dambethenne Tea Factory. My parents, who are in their early 70s had no issues with this walk down. On the way we bumped into a young family and made our way back with them. We took our time to savor the views, take pictures and talk to the plantation workers as we weaved down.

The road to this place is very narrow. recommended to travel in a jeep or a car. large vehicles are not recommended. Also do not travel on rainy days. superb view. According to the people there you could see an Ariel view of 5 provinces of Sri Lanka. Only problem is there is no proper restaurant for refreshments and no toilet facilities. They charge to enter this place. Can not understand why that money could be utilized to improve the infra structure.

You can get a car to the top but we walked from the tea factory up through the tea plantations to the Liptons seat.  It is 3hr return but well worth it for the views on the way and the friendly locals who live on the hills.  Take plenty of water although there is a shop at the top to restock. The route is easy and you don't need a guide.  Our kids of 11 and 13 were easily able to make the walk.

Apparently you can see 5 provinces from the same spot. Perched high above spectacular tea gardens overlooking patchwork valleys and mountains is Lipton's Seat and didn't Sir Thomas Lipton have the best view. The road is narrow, winding around the hills with too many hairpin turns to count but without a doubt it is worth the drive. It is 100 rupees per car plus 50 rupees per person weather you drive or walk to the summit. Get some beautiful panoramic photographs plus some selfies with Sir Thomas Lipton's statue likeness. There is a small cafe serving tea and Sri Lankan treats which is affordable and the staff are friendly. Highly highly recommend.

Worth making the trip to Haputale just to do Liptons Seat! We stayed at a guesthouse in Haputale and got a tuk tuk at 6am to the Dambatenne tea factory (700 rupees around 30min journey). From there we followed the winding road up to liptons seat. It's a very easy 7km walk up and I would definitely recommend walking rather than getting a tuk tuk to the top if you have time! A tuk tuk straight to the top costs around 1000rupees apparently. For the way up we followed the gentle winding road but on the way down we took the steeper routes straight down the tea plantation which is definitely faster (would make for a very strenuous hike up hill though). It's a 50 rupees entrance fee to enter the last part of the walk to get to liptons seat. The views through the tea plantation are absolutely stunning, we were lucky to go on a sunny day. It took us about an hour and a half to get to the top and we stopped for a cup of tea, there's a hut selling tea and rottis with lots of local Sri Lankan guys trying to get you to eat there. Views at the top are also amazing but make sure to get there early as the fog rolls in mid morning. The way down is pretty fast if you take the steps down the tea plantation (you'll see them on the side of the road). We went to the tea factory for a tour then got the local bus back to Haputale and were back in town by around 11:30am.

Whether you walk the 7.5km uphill or get a tuk tuk the views are incredible.  Many sure you arrive early and stay and grab some rotti at the top.  Walking back down through the plantations is truly stunning.
Don't miss out on this. Cheap tuk tuk there. Beautiful landscape. Free entry. Very peaceful and enjoyable.

Amazing way from Dambatene to Lipton Seat between tea plant with workers like from 19th century. Unbelievable. On the top is small lovely restaurant  with tea and simple Sri Lanka food. The biggest experince in Sri Lanka.

The trip up is by Tuk-tuk but a few hardy souls walked through the tea plantation to get there and saved themselves the fare (3000R). We were forewarned on the day that we visited that we would be lucky to get a good view from the toil and sure enough it was swathed in low cloud when we arrived with only the briefest glimpse throughout the cloud after about 40 minutes. Local Macaques abound and raid the bins of a nearby refreshment shop, which also supplies tasty curry at not-too-exorbitant prices, given the transporting costs! A bronze statue of Sir Thomas Lipton on a board seat invites you to be photo'd there. Despite the briefest glimpse through the mist, it was worth seeing.

This turned out to be a much better site than we expected.  We were amazed at the beauty of the area with the vista from the top of the valleys and the surrounding tea plantations.  Early morning is the best time to visit.  We were there by 8am, and the clouds moved in and obscured the view about 8:45am.  The little cafe at the site is OK, but not great.  We recommend taking a tuk tuk to the top (beautiful ride) and walking down, taking a few shortcuts through the tea fields on established paths.
This must be at your to do list in central Srilanka. Amazing view. We take tuk tuk from Haputale to the top for 1000 R. On the top is nice tea shop and you can enjoy cup of tea and the view.

We loved hiking through the tea fields! When you reach the top, you'll be at Lipton's seat. There's a small tea house where you can sit, have a tea and enjoy the view. View was awesome, the tea was the worst tea of whole Sri Lanka!! But it was a funny experience.

Commencing from Haputale town, it 's a 9 km uphill climb. The climb if in a vehicle its a tough and precarious climb with hair pin bends in a narrow road through tea plantation. At the peak you could watch most of the country as far as the coast line if the sky is clear and the weather is good. Always it is wise to select a sunny day to trek . Don't fail to carry your snacks and enough water to drink as the climb is tough.

One of the greatest locations in Sri Lanka. Amazing view. Make sure to take a tuk tuk from Dambetenna Estate. The road is windy & very narrow. One could see 7 out of the 9 provinces in the country. Mr.Lipton would have loved to be here !!!

Incredible views over the plantations and several mountain ranges all around you. Breathtaking, but be sure to be there before 10am before the fog hits the peaks and visibility decreases or becomes non-existent ;) The way up and the scenery is definitely worth setting your alarm clock. The Dambatenne tea plantation is very well-kept and beautiful, and it's worth taking shortcuts through it and walk around (as opposed to only driving up and down). There are many ways you can reach the Lipton Seat panorama, from Haputale : bus to dambatenne tea factory (about 10km) + another small bus or tuktuk to the lipton seat gate (or hike but mind the heat) (about 5km) + uphill hike or tuktuk to the top (1 km). At the Haputale tuktuk stand, drivers will be happy to negociate a cheap fee up to the very top, as there are few tourists. There is a small entrance fee (50 rps ?) at the Lipton Seat gate (1km from the top) (+vehicle fee so you might also want to ride a tuktuk to that point and walk up)
Very beautiful place to visit.Road conditions are not too good. Recommend to visit using small vehicle.

You can walk here from Dambatene factory or take a bus. It's a defintely one of the best places with the views I have ever been to! The come back from here to Haputale by walking will take you minimum 3 hours among tea plantations . I loved it even despite heavy rain.

An amazing view and well worth the walk from the gate. I wouldn't start climbing up from the tea factory unless it's a cool day. However, did walk all the way back down to the factory. Lovely walk and the tea pickers are just so kind. There is a very funky little tea hut at the top and it's well worth having a cup and chatting with the host, narayanan.

Get up to Liptons Seat for some truly breathtaking views... and a nice cup of tea!The colours and contrasts are the best at dawn. Still a beautiful to visit at anytime of day but beware of the cloud decending late morning, early pm. We took a tuk tuk on the way up and walked back through the tea plantations to Haputale, about 16km by road.  Sri Lanka is a very special place but this is one of the finest

This is a nice place to visit in Haputale where you can feel the hill country atmosphere. It has a nice background while climbing the Lipton seat. Once we reach the top there are 2 shops at the top to have a small snack. People over there explains about the Lipton seat and what we see around. Nice place to go.

I'm up early, eat breakfast at hotel & off to Lipton's Seat. I take a local bus UPHILL  to Dambatenne Tea Factory (RS 30). It takes 30‚Äù. It's 9 kms. On the spur of the moment I take a tuk-tuk (RS 500) UPHILL to Lipton's Seat. I don't bargain, first he says RS 600 but I say too much, then he says RS 500 & I go okay. It's 7-8 kms & takes 20‚Äù. I'm glad I did that. It is foggy & blusterous up there. I stay a few minutes and saunter & mosey DOWNHILL back to Dambatenne Tea Factory. That takes 3+ hours. It's splendiferous scenery. I take tooooooooooo many pictures (Sorry) but the views are BEA-utiful.

We took a tuk tuk to the tea factory then walked up to Lipton's seat and back. We then walked back to Haputale, making this a substantial walk of about 24 km but you can do as much or as little walking as you want by taking the bus or a tuk tuk. We had good weather and found the scenery amazing. Precisely manicured tea plants covering every spare inch of hillside. New views unfolding as you get higher. Quite a few other tourists up at the top but not at all crowded. All together one of our favourite walks so far in Sri Lanka.

While it's recommended to go early in the morning for clear views, we decided to take a more leisurely trip later.  We took a tuk tuk from Haputale to the Dambatenne Tea Factory and walked the road and some shorts cuts to the top - Lipton's seat. We much enjoyed the views on the way and seeing the tea pickers at work.  I received many looks of amusement and perhaps disapproval on account of my walking sticks and hiking boots, which surely seemed way over the top, but I also exchanged a good number of smiles. When we reached the top at least half of the view was covered in mist, but we really didn't mind.  It was the journey for us that mattered more than the "prize".  And, the restaurant at the top had surprisingly good food and perhaps the best tea I tasted on our entire trip. We walked back down to the tea factory and were lucky enough to catch a local bus back to Haputale which was a super fun experience -- devotional tchotchkes on the dashboard and popular Hindi music playing all the way for a cheap price. Definitely worth the visit.
We went up by Tuk Tuk and at first I thought why? However it is quite a hike so I would recommend this. Once you arrive the views are amazing and well worth going
Count 1h20 to go up and 45 min to go down. Beautiful walk in the middle of the tea plantations. View there is amazing. Try to get there early in the morning as the clouds go up at around 9:30-10am.
You can get the bus from Haputale which takes you 2 km away from the top point. Views are amazing if you have good weather. During our visit it was very windy. Take warm clothes.

We visited Lipton's Seat while staying at Haputale. The advice was to get a taxi to drop us off at the top, walk the 7 kilometres downhill through the tea plantations and catch a bus back to Haputale from Dambatenne which we duly did; we were not disappointed. We got to the top by 06.00 which was plenty of time to settle down and wait for the sun to rise. At that time of the morning, and at that height, it gets pretty cold so I definitely recommend a fleece and windproof. The views are stunning but of course are totally dependant on the weather. We were lucky and had great 360 degree panoramic views; absolutely stunning and an experience that will stay with us forever. At the top you can get hot tea and roti freshly cooked over a wood fire which was very welcome after our early morning start. The walk downhill (I note some reviewers walked up as well as down - I consider myself to be a strong walker and I wouldn't have liked to have done that so hats off to them!) is equally enjoyable. The incredible views of the summit are gradually replaced by rolling tea plantations and tea planters villages until finally the tea factory at Dambatenna comes into view. All in all a wonderful experience although, of course, totally dependant on the weather. Here's wishing you good luck on the weather front when you get the chance to visit Lipton's Seat.

Sunrise was awesome ...... Incredible views of the Uva Plains .... too bad the haze filters the view of the ocean, horizon and the Great Basses lighthouse .... peaks of Horton Plains, World's End viewpoint, Namunu Kula, Mt. Pedro (Hay Beaten Rock) mountain range, Mt. Kiri Galpoththa (Milky Rock Shell) peak, WangediGala Peaks (Crater mountain valley/peaks, Knuckles Range,& Atompitia range ....  Highly Recommended for sunrise hike and Dambetenne Tea Fields ... broken orange pekoe .... silver tips .... Enjoyable .... Hve Fun !!! .....

We parked at Dambattene tea factory and walked up to Liptons Seat and back down. The return trip took us about 3 hours and was well worth the effort. It is recommended that you get to the top before 11am as after this time the mist increases and the views are not as good. On the way up and down you don't have to follow the road put can use the paths through the tea plantations as short cuts.
A perilous journey that our hotel driver handled safely and well. Stunning scenery. Well with the trip.
Really a nice place to visit.v went there by car..beware f taxi drivers near tea factory.they ll tell u, its hard to drive to the top..quite difficult,but u can..bring a jacket as its too cold

Be careful of the local taxi-drivers who know that they have you by the short & curlies. It is worth persevering, get a good price and get a lift up to Lipton's seat and then you can walk down to the Tea Factory and they will pick you up from there. It is a brilliant walk and all downhill. Make sure you are down by midday though as it starts to get misty and the views become limited and it seems that you are walking over the Yorkshire Moors and not the Sri Lankan Uplands.
since rainy before so that not so many people at there when i reached lipton's seat around 9am something. weather was varied every moment but i got stunning view finally.

We considered walking but opted for a tuk tuk ride which I would seriously recommend.  It's a big hike otherwise but the views are spectacular and you can't help but wonder about Thomas and his royal parties in that spot a hundred years ago.  Sunrise is a great time to visit, you'll get some awesome photographs.

awesome view in the morning, but very difficult drive by a car as the road is narrow. Road quality dramatically deteriorate after the ticket gate, which is absurd. No sanitary or other visitor service provided for the fee they charging from the visitors.

We took the easy way up but many walk up or down or both - a great way to meet the locals in the tea plantations. It is quite a climb even in a car but the views are well worth it and it was not crowded at the top despite the numbers seen making their way up and down.

We took a bus from Haputale to the tea factory and then walked to Lipton's Seat..it's amazing there - beautiful views of tea plantations with local people and children going to school and work (if you go early in the morning)..there is a small fee to pay if you want to go up (50Rp)..at the top, there's a small 'hotel' with bunch of crazy guys who will start offering everthing from the menu to get some money of you :) It's a good idea to take some jacket, it can be quite cold there. In the end, we walked all the way to Bandarawella where we took a train back to Haputale - it was a long trip :)

Situated in Dambethanna Estate, Haputale. Road to the place is very narrow. You must have a great amount of calmness if you are driving yourself. I got nearly one and half hour to reach the top by my jeep. A group of estate staff manage the entrance to the place, because there is only a ten vehicle space at the summit point. Roadside is also scenic. Avoid cloudy seasons unless you will not be able to watch.
It took us along time by scooter to find this. We travelled from Ella! Worth it in the end! It was very misty up there and the views all the way up by scooter were incredible!

This is an excellent place for stunning photos. Make sure you are visiting it early in the morning between 5.30-8:00am  Also make sure it's a clear day. Best for nature lovers. Views are greenery. Fresh air.

We were based in Ella and decided to get the train to Haputale (roughly 1 hour)  then a tuk tuk up to the Dambetenne tea factory. From there it is a lovely 7.5km walk up the road to Lipton's seat. The route winds through the tea fields and the little districts where the workers live and every person greets you with a friendly smile and a wave. It took us about 1.5hr to get to the top at a leisurely pace and were met with some incredible views. We had to pay 50lkr each to proceed to the top and it looked like any vehicles required 100lkr. We then decided to walk all the way back to Haputale which was about 9-10km from the tea factory. This walk is not too arduous as it's fairly flat but can be tiring in the afternoon sun. NOTE: There are a lot of local kids on the way to Liptons seat and walk to Haputale who ask for the obligatory sweet/cookie etc.but also ask for school pens. Unfortunately we did not have a single pen between us but I'd recommend stocking up before visiting so you can become the local hero!
Took a trip to Lipton's seat to see the sunrise. It was a truly beautiful experience! I would certainly recommend this.

A short ride into the hills and the Lipton Tea plantation surrounds you. This place can be either reached by a quick hike or a tuk tuk ride. There is a small toll fee to be paid but its totally worth it. You get a chance to jump between the tea shrubs.

Great trip with great views and a lot of friendly smiles and talks with locals. Not that crowded at the top. Would recommend to take a TukTuk to the top and then walk down to the tea factory and take a bus or TukTuk home to Haputale.

You can easily hike from the Dambatenne Tea Factory to the top and back (it's two hours to the top and hour and a half back). On your beautiful, refreshing and not-at-all demanding way up, you'll be passed by old people in tuk-tuks (understandable), handicapped people in tuk-tuks (also understandable) and able-bodied lazy loosers in tuk-tuks (not understandable at all). Please, make fun of them. Also, hike. The view is much more rewarding if you walked it up. On the top, you can get some food, water and tea as well (the tea on Lipton's Seat is highly recommended and it costs only 200 rupees for the whole pot!). Entrance fee is 50 rupees for foreign visitors.
It's worth watching this spectacular view. Nice drive through tea plantations. Shouldn't miss this wonderful place.

Even though we had some fog, the trek up here was totally worthwhile.  Take the tuk-tuk - too far to walk.  Beautiful tea gardens and hills, and view from the top is exceptional.  Early in the day is best.

On a clear day, you can see 5 provinces and 2 seas. Just thinking of that can be baffling, and I'm certain it'll be an awe-inspiring and humbling experience. If the day is misty, then you won't see much but it's still a magical, mystical experience to be amongst the clouds. If you do choose to come here, you can avoid staying in Haputale as there isn't no much to do there. Also, you can go up to Lipton's Seat by van, tuk-tuk, or spend quite a bit of time climbing up and down.
We highly recommend a tuk tuk ride early in the morning to reach the Lipton seat. The view is dramatic and the hike downhill is unforgettable.
Bit of a drive to get there, but really great lookout across the whole area on a clear day. Beware of foggy weather though. A lot of beautiful tea plantations on the way.
If you are lucky with a sunny day, this is an excellent place for stunning photos of this beautiful countryside and the smiling ladies picking tea in the hills below!

Instead of hiking we were driven up, first in a car and the last stretch in a tuk tuk. The views were breathtakingly beautiful along the way too. We made a stop at the tea leaves weighing station. It was on their first working day of the year, it felt very festive and all the tea pickers were chatty and happy. Quite an experience to see the mass quantity of rice and curry being prepared.

We went there by scouter. Don't be discouraged by clouds- they come and go making the trip even more picturesque. On d way I see local people, children, tea plantation workers. Very nice day exploring local area.

It's important land mark in haputale. good observation point. around 15-17km from haputhale drive to the top. good experience drive to top on small road. we are very lucky sunny day.spot up to hambantota sea.you can see all the provinces of sri lanka. I think it's belong to dabethenna tea factory. i can imagine how enjoy mr.thomas lipton in the evening with this amazing view.
A very touristic place but, nonetheless a beautiful view over the tea plantations.  A nice climb to arrive to the Seat

If you are on a vehicle with a reasonable ground clearance you can drive to the place by yourself. A Normal car with 14", 15" rim size wheels will do. There are lot of Tuktuk drivers in Haputale Rail station, but they may charge ~1500LKR for the trip. Negotiate the price BEFORE YOU GET IN. Another good choice is you can drive up to the tea factory (Dambetenna Tea factory), visit the factory, leave the car there, and take a tuk-tuk to the Lipton's Seat. Don't forget two things; first, go early, earlier the better; second stop at local vegetable selling places go to their back yard with them; you can pick up vegetables by yourself, amazing experience !!!

We opted to go to Lipton's Seat over World's End as it was on our way to Ella and that it is significantly cheaperl. We got into Haputale late, got up early and took a tuk tuk in the morning to Lipton's Seat. If you get dropped off at the gate it's about a 1.2 km walk with a beautiful view. If you walk from the tea factory at the base it's about 7-9km. The entrance fee is 100lkr per person.

Take a tuktuk from Railway station and offer the guy 1200 or 1300 LKR to visit both Lipton Seat and Tea Factory. Pay him 100 for every additional time you want to stay at either of the place. If you are not strong enough at hiking, then you may consider visiting this place or Little Adam's Peak instead of going to the Adam's Peak at Hatton.
You take a risk with the clouds but even though our view was limited once we reached the top our journey up was great if a little sad seeing all the hard working tea puckers.

Went by local bus from Haputale to Dambattene and walked from there to the top. An absolutly amazing walk among the tea plantions with views to die for. Took approximatly 1,5 hours for us to reach the top. Don't miss if you are in the surroundings! But go early morning to escape the mist coming in during day time.
Very nice place and very misty and beautiful You can see five different locations when you go up there The drive is superb . Better take a Trishaw from half way as its difficult to drive.
A definite place to visit in Haputale. I love the sceneries . I can spend hours at Lipton Seat by looking at the views.... Beautiful place to be at least once in your lifetime.

I was waiting for this experience and finally got it! At 1897 m above mean sea level, breathtaking views of 5 provinces.  There is a nice kiosk  which serves hot food (South indian to popular snack food) and tea and water and soft drinks. Owner is Narayan is a 100 % service oriented guy. You can call him on 763579504. ,(picture attached). Also , I found a helpful tuk tuk driver who provided transport in a spacious tuk tuk. He is Wasantha ( 0722951478) and photo attached. Both are reliable and can be recommended.

The route from the Dambatenne tea factory is well signed, just keep walking uphill! Through tea plantations, very scenic, will take about 1 hr 30 mins to the top walking at reasonable pace. There is a gate at the last 1km were you pay 50 rupees to enter (the guard tried asking 100 each, just say no and point to the price on the sign). We were unlucky and had mist at the top, but the whole walk was great and a nice cheap thing to do for a morning or afternoon.

The place is magic. I could sit there and watch the tea plantations over and over.... So many shades of green (not grey!!!). Had a cup of tea with my girlfriend and was nice and tasty (they put fresh ginger in it). It is simply a must visit and see place.

We went to Lipton Seat with a tuck-tuck (800 roupies from Haputale to the entrance). Unfortunately at the top it was foggy by the time we arrived. Nevertheless we hiked all the way down. We were a bit disappointed that the path was just the way back on the concrete road. Still a nice walk trough the tea plantations.

This was one of the highlights of our whole trip to Sri Lanka. We went for dawn, which was beautiful though bring some warmer clothes. Views were breathtaking. Go for breakfast afterwards at the local cafe for tea, chapatti and sambol....we had it for 4 people at a cost of 500 rupees!! Best meal view ever- just watch the monkeys don't steal your food! We lost a few chapatti! Walk down to the Dambatenne tea factory through the tea plantation, if you also go at dawn it's perfectly timed to see the workers heading out in the morning. They were happy for you to take photos and didn't expect paid- again showing it's less touristy. The tea factory is fascinating, much cheaper value than other more famous and touristy venues- it cost up 500 rupees per person. We got the sense we were flies on the wall Andrew that they didn't many tourists. So you saw the real process, rather than a sanatised version for tourists- fascinating, you'll never look at your tea in the same way again. Don't expect a tea shop at the end! This is a black tea factory predominately.

This is just 15 kilometers ride/walk with breathtaking landscapes. There are buses leaving from Haputale town to Dambatenna tea factory, the final stretch of the journey can be completed either hiring a Tuk Tuk or walking. Start the trail as early as possible.

Car can only reach Dambatenne Tea Factory and from there we changed tuktuk. It was a 6~7 km ride to the top and I am glad we did go there. The Lipton's seat location is private property so you'll have to pay by entrance (forgot how much but it's cheap).And if you wanna enjoy tea farm view all the way up it's about 30~40 mins walk (~2 km). There's no toilet inside so be prepared. On the top you may see Lipton's (Sir. Thomas.J.Lipton) statue and a beautiful view from top of the hill. You can also enjoy a fresh cup of tea from the tea plantation and some snacks there. Our driver was surprised (he'd never been there) and said he'd definitely recommend this place to his customer in the future.
there is a must see view from the top and a very nice way back. better take tuk tuk the way up and walk the way down (better with a map or an app).

We had a Tuk-tuk take us up to Lipton's seat. The road is tight hairpin bends all the way up through the tea plantations, so not easy by car and it is a long way on foot. All along the way the views just get better and better. Once on the top the panoramic view is breathtaking. Oh.. and you can get a nice cup of tea while you admire the view. Go early in the day or you might be sharing it with too many people.

From Haputale, get the local bus to dambatenne (rs30/pers), it is only 15 minutes ride. And from there you can start to walk to the Lipton seat. 6 km through the tea plantation and local village to get to the top. It is a easy walk and not so many cars. You will be charge rs50 when you get close to the top. Probably the best and most enjoyable think I've done here in Sri Lanka, landescape are breathtaking, people along the road are so nice, and nobody is trying to sell you anything. There is a fews school on the road, if you go there, take some pen with you to give out to the kids you met on your way up, they will be more than happy! On the top, there is a little shop, selling tea coffee soda.. they even cook some very good samosa! Please do not miss them, the 2 gentlemens are very kind, and the price is more than reasonable. Be aware that some monkey will try to rob your food. A must do in Sri Lanka, and by walk!! Don't wast your money with a tuktuk.

Unlike many attractions in Sri Lanka walking up to Lipton's Seat is free. Get the bus from Haputale to Dambatenne and from there just keep walking up and up. It's one road littered with sign post and odd quotes about the environment.  The walk is stunning going through field after field of tea bushes, past pluckers and farmers and schools You can take the road or cut through the fields using the stairs (use google maps just to make sure) or follow the steady stream of tourists. We went in the afternoon because we were coming from Ella and although at times it was cloudy and drizzly it all passed very quickly to become sunny again so don't worry too much if you can't make it in the morning. Be warned. We you get near the top you do have to pay 50r per person to enter (100r if you take a vehicle). We weren't aware of this before but luckily we had change on us and the guard taking money even lent us his umbrella because he saw rain coming. The view at the top is incredible and the small shack/cafe is reasonably priced. They even allowed us to hide inside theur hut during the torrential downpour that surprised us at the top. A grand day out.

One of the best places in our country. The view is stunning, Whole place is covered by mist. We went there by about 10.30 a.m. But the mist has covered the whole area. Has a long walk by the foot path besides Mr.Lipton. Amazing! Your eyes should see this stunning view. Feels that this is a jungle in a cold country!

Best walk on vacation. Go early morning with the bus to the tea factory.than take a tuktuk 7km up to the lipton seat. Enjoy the view and than take a walk down. Use the shorter ways and get lost in green color everywhere. Just beautyful place.
The drive from Ella through the tea plantations to Liptons Seat are gorgeous.  We walked part of the way but I would recommend you walk the whole way if you're up to it.  The scenery is spectacular.

We took a Tuk Tuk from Olympus Plaza Hotel to Lipton's Seat for Rs.1200. It was a  clear dry day so we were lucky. Next time I want to visit to witness the sunrise & walk back. Its 18kms one way & takes 50min to go up in a tuk tuk.

It's the best to get there before 7am by a threewheeler. The view on top is great but what's better is the walk downhill. There are tea plantations all over the mountain, and everywhere looks like a painting. You could see workers going to work and picking tea leaves starting around 9am. Finish off the walk with a visit to the tea factory and learn about how tea leaves are made.

A 360 view of a hill top Lipton seat was the worlds famous historical place located in dambatene, a place that every foreign people must visit.  A few steps to heaven that how tired you may walk to reach it, it's a stress reliever and pain relief once you reach the top.  Fresh air,  Amazing view,  feels like you are in heaven.  Just a reminder before going,  just bring enough water and food as there's no foreign food available once you reach on the top

The best time to visit or rather make it worthwhile is visiting it early in the morning between 6:30-8:00am because if you go after this time, then sun will be up and the fog will come down and will be difficult to have a good view, also make sure it's on a clear day. It can take around 1 & half hours to reach from Bandarawela. If you are to drive there, make sure you are taking a van or an suv, if it's a car, make sure it has high ground clearance and good tyres. The drive on the way up can be a little difficult as the roads are very narrow such that only one vehicle may pass. But the view on the way up can be breathtakingly beautiful. On a clear day, you'd be able to see Hambantota and the view of the sea. Despite it being a difficult drive, it's well worth the effort.

This I such a beautiful hike, especially with the sunset! It' s best to leave at 4.45 (yes I know, very early...but so worth it!) a tuktuk Will cost you around 1000r to be there in time. You Will walk your way back through the theeplantations until you reachbthe Lipton teafactory, wich is deffinately worth a visit (250r) as well! From there you can take a bus of tuktuk back to Haputale.

We walked from Dambatenne tea factory up and up and up (even using some short cuts) but it was worth it. Sunrise was 5.45am. Monkeys posed for us at liptons seat, but we didn't feed them. Coming down is much quicker and easier. Tuk tuk 500rs to Haputale.
One of the most beautiful view in the country Some drivers don't like to drive there because of the road conditions but my driver sisira took me there great view

As there were 4 of us we took a pair of tuk tuks from our guest house to the top of Lipton's Seat which is about 5,000 feet in elevation. The road wound its way up and up through the tea plantations round countless hairpin bends (not dangerous) before reaching the entrance gate where there is a small entrance fee to be paid. The views from the top are almost 360 degrees and are stunning. We were possibly lucky with the weather as it was a cloudless deep blue sky and we could see for miles in all directions.The vivid green of the tea plantations set against the sky was very photogenic......lots of photos to be taken here!! At the top there is a fine statue of Mr Lipton himself and a small cafe where we sat and enjoyed the views. The air was cooler here and although it was hot when we were there I can imagine on a cloudier day it could be pretty chilly! Instead of taking the tuk tuk back down we decided to walk back down through the tea plantations. This was superb, we took it at a leisurely pace and just enjoyed the scenery, the friendliness of the locals particularly the smiling schoolchildren who make their way up and down this steep hill every day! We walked as far as the Dambatenne Tea Factory and then took a tuk tuk back to town from there. This was yet another highlight of our trip and one i highly recommend.....away from the crowds too!
Beautiful views from the top of the hill. The scenery getting there is through tea estate, with tea pluckers and workers going about their jobs.

We arrived Haputale in the morning and decided to go to Lipton's Seat in the afternoon. Luckily, the weather was really good, clear sky and not foggy. We took tuk tuk one way to the lipton seat and had to walk for 1.4 km to the top. The walk is one of our beautiful experiences in here: tea platation around you. We didnt want take tuk tuk to get down. The tuk tuk driver said that it's around 2-2.30 hour to get bus station ( dambutale tea factory) but we needed only 110 minutes. We always foud shortcut way between tea platation. It's crazy and exciting. We had a great time in here. Beautiful town! The last bus is 5.45 pm from factory to town center.

It is worth the stress to put an alarm clock even on holiday. But when you will be there, almost yourself, looking at the hills pointed out by the trees...you will understand. The walk can be long, so if you are not really willing to enjoy also the trekking to reach the seat, book a tuk tuk or rent a scooter.
An amazing site with beautiful landscapes on thevwasy. A view of greenery and an eco friendly environment. A place to breathe fresh air. Nature invites us free of charge.
Visit with my friends. Must visit place where you can see three provinces together. cool climate. loved very much. Its better to go by your own feet. i did it. amazing experience.

The Lipton Seat hillstop is like any other viewpoint in Sri Lanka. You can see 5 diatricts from above and the view is beautiful. The tea plantations etched beautifully across the mountain side is just gorgeous. We took a car up and it was slightly difficult as the road was rather narrow. But if you are willing to pay a Tuk Tuk driver about 1000 rupees, he will take you there and back. It will be a unique experience indeed.

Left Haputale around 4.30am. Took about an hour for the winding drive to the start of the walk up to Liptons Seat. The walk itself is uphill on good paths/roads, took about 2 hrs to reach Liptons seat, it's a lovely walk, thoroughly recommend it. Arrived just after sunrise, should of left Haputale a bit earlier, say 4am. Rewarded with truly stunning views, would do it again for sure. There is a small place at the top where you can get a cuppa tea and a rotti - absolutely lovely and with that view - a breakfast to remember! You can of course drive all the way to the top and then walk down, this should guarantee you sunrise and you get the beautiful views on walk down. I walked up and down as I had the time. I would definitely walk up or down as it's just beautiful through the tea plantations. A fantastic way to spend the morning! Can finish off at the tea factory when you come down.

Long way up, but worth it. Stunning views all the way to the top. We took a Tuk Tuk which was a good decision. The road is narrow and not really suitable for anything bigger. Some people walked, but it's a long way.

One of the best hiking point through tea planted mountains. It's good to be there early in the morning to capture sun rise scene. Point is very good for those who loves photography. Pleasant views all around at top.

Make sure to get there early and arrive before the fog sets in. We drove in from Haputale which is a one and a half hour drive. Leave at least at 4.45 h. It's a 3-4 hours walk and if you want to move on afterwards to Ella for example, you can take your luggage and ask to be dropped at the nearest train station. (in between Nuwara Eliya and Haputale. Take breakfast with you and enjoy it at World's End. You don't have to pay for toilets on arrival, although a guy will certainly try you for it :) Don't leave youre garbage in the park!!!

Lipton's Seat was added to our trip by our experienced tour guide. We were travelling on our honeymoon and he went out of his way to make it extra special. We were surprised to discover this was only his second time up to Lipton's Seat! The tuk tuk ride up was unforgettable, twists and turns and amazing views. When we reached the top I was amazed by the view, luckily we had a clear day and could see out over all 5 districts! I felt on top of the world and could have sat for hours, it was very peaceful at the top and not many visitors which added to the serenity! I definitely recommend this trip if you have the time!

The walk through the plan at ions is nice enough but we found the best view was actually off the beaten track pretty early in the walk.  From liptons seat it was too misty to see anything and it seems this is common. Perhaps arriving very early morning would have been worthwhile (we arrived around 10.30am).
The view was obscured by cloud, but the walk back to the tea factory through the plantations is scenic and a fascinaing insight into the area.
i'd recommend tuktuk up and walking back down. Don't be afraid of the shortcuts through the tea flields that the tea workers use as they cut out a lot of switchbacks on the road.

A nice morning walk through the tea plantations to this amazing view. Would definitely go again! If you don't mind walking, then walk both up and down and don't get the tuktuk driver to drive you one way - it is not that far!
this is the best place to get your view with your camera.really nice place to visit.Enjoyed.the road was little bit harder to go there.
If you're a nature lover it's a must visit place ! Amazing view the ride it self is great , expect narrow roads when you get close to the location !

Great spot to see sunrise. Nice, leisurely walk down the paved road through the tea plantation and village with vegetable gardens and on to the tea factory. Some people use the tea picker paths as shortcuts down the mountain.

Amazing beautiful point, have to go there. It's not just top of the mountain, there is more than something, feeling. We took the tuktuk from the station to here.(return 1400rs) this nice driver stopped several times for take photos.
Make sure to go early in the morning! It's not cloudy and quiet, and you have a beautiful view. Visiting the Tea Factory is nice, cross fingers for a well english speaking guide. :-)

Lipton's seat is definitely one of the must visit places in Sri Lanka. Recommended to reach there before 6am in order to catch the sunrise. Along the way to Lipton's seat, we were surrounded by tea plantations and the view is stunning.

When I visited, it was shrouded in mist so I could not see much - but the view on the ride up was beautiful. You can either trek or take a tuk up; entry up to Lipton's Seat is lkr100/pax (you pay for your tuk driver as well). However, I hear that the view is amazing if you are lucky enough to catch it without mist.

Lipton's Seat - A touch-upon the Colonial Tea Industry !!!! This unbelievably beautiful breathtaking location is in  Haputale. Once you turn from Haputale road you need to travel nearly 28 Kilometers. Once you have reached Damabetenna estate you are closer to the site. Big buses or bigger vans are not possible on this route. Recommend to park your vehicle by the Dambetenna Tea factory premises & hop in to  a tuk tuk by the park. The local boys are pretty knowledgeable about the   site. Through a tiny little windy road you could reach the peak. Once you reach the Lipton's seat you will not believe your eyes. This has been the location where Mr.Thomas Lipton has done his surveying for Tea planting. You could see five Provinces in Sri Lanka from the location. The breeze & the view will take you to a paradise. There is a lookout point a little away from the seat. Down side is the lack of any toilet facility .  The Tea estate currently belongs to Lankem group.

You can get a tuk-tuk or taxi all the way to the top, but you should if there was a god be mercilessly mocked for all eternity. Purists would walk all the way up and down, this would be the most authentic and to you I hold my hat up high. I am not however made of such stern stuff and would recommend getting to the entrance (about 20 minutes walk from the top) which is just the right balance of civilisation and sweat Once at the top it commands a 360 view that is quite magnificent. Then walk back down to get a bus to Haputale back for a late breakfast / early brunch.

We took a tuktuk to the very top (you have to pay 50rs per person extra at a checkpoint) in the afternoon and walked the way down. It's a spectacular view from the top but also walking down is just beautiful. The tea pluckers just got off from work and we could watch them getting their tea weighed. We enjoyed this walk so much that we went back a second time for sunrise (a bit before 6am) and we're glad we did that was just amazing. Did the same thing - tuk tuk up, walk down. Together with all the children on their way to school.

We visited Lipton's seat around 11am after the clouds has rolled in. Our friend has a tuk tuk so we took one all the way up as we didn't want to risk walking to have no views. It was as we had expected, a pea souper (very cloudy), but this didn't remove much from the experience. Ascending we would find gaps in the clouds to see the views. If you arrive before 10am, more often than not you will beat the banks of clouds that roll in and be treated to a stunning panormama. The cup of tea at the top from the caf√© is ok, I would have preferred a pot of Orange Pekoe given that we ARE in one of the best tea producing regions in the world. So the slightly standard cup of tea offered, along with rotty was adequate at best. Don't read me as a snob here, I just think it's something that would at least be nice as an option! If you stop to photograph any of the Tamil pickers as you climb, please bear in mind their very poor income is supported a little here by the tourism. What can be a beautiful photo for you can translate to a weeks food for them and their family. Do not however, support begging. There is a bus that services up to around 2km from the summit at the cost of around 90Lkr. It is only small though and runs hourly from the town. Ask fruit sellers near the bus stop as for the next time it runs.

The view is breathtaking! Couldn't ask for a better view. Roads leading to this place are a bit challenging. Sometimes there could be a lot of mist covering the view so be sure to go early during daytime.
Breathtaking views across miles of tea plantation. You can get up by tuk tuk and walk down. Cup of tea available in very rustic room at the top. Nb no toilet

Took a mini bus from the back of the bus station (told by the fruit stall seller) it just cost bout rs90. It will stopped in the plantation and we gotto walk up for another 2.2km. it was nice walk with the breeze. We hiked up in between the plantation it's just beautiful! Magnificent sight. Do be warn about the steep road, some tuktuk and private vans can still be drove up and it's pretty scary too. Go up and have a pic with Mr.Lipton who will be seating there and wait.

I didn t understand why people take a tuc tuc to go directly to Lipton seat ! The view by walk of the amazing tea plantation worth it so much, the 7 kilometer are very fast if you do it in the early morning. This is the best tea plantation i've seen so far, the view at lipton seat is nice but from haputale there is the same. This is the walk until lipton seat that worth it !

Our group was transported to Lipton's Seat, arriving around 9am. We could all see the gorgeous passing scenery during the ascent, but didn't anticipate such a stunning view upon alighting the mini bus. WOW - no other word except wow escaped our lips. We were on top of the world. I've never experienced something so beautiful. We then strolled over to the lookout for another view, and had to pinch ourselves. To top off the amazing experience, we enjoyed morning tea at the base of the lookout: hot roti, laddu and the freshest single origin tea going around. It was truly a money-can't-buy experience and one I will treasure for a long time.

We left our hotel near Haputale at 6am, for the 1hour+ ride to Lipton's Seat. There was only one other couple there when we arrived. After admiring the view and watching the monkeys in the nearby trees, we had the picnic breakfast supplied by our hotel. It was beautiful to stand there (no seats), eating, while taking in the view. Definitely a must, but don't attempt to walk unless you are extremely fit.
We walked up first thing in the morning while the workers and were coming out and kids were going to school. About 7km, but definitely worth it. Absolutely stunning views at the top

We left Haputale city at 8 and reached Lipton‚Äôs seat 8.45. The view from the top was stunning! We had some tea with snacks before starting walking down the tea plantage which is 7 km. It's a beautiful area and very well organised. You can see and talk to the workers along the walk. In the end of the walk you can visit and enter the factory for only 250 rp per person.

Though a long ride, it was extremely worthwhile. When I first went to Nuwara Errors and Lake Gregory, I thought these two places are most beautiful. But after visiting Haputale and Lipton's Seat, my memory stuck in the later two places only.
Was an enjoyable experience,  older couples need to get transport. The only negative is there are no toilets.

Great views of tea plantations and eucalyptus trees, interesting ride with the tuc tuc uphill and a great cantine with local pies and "wade"... It is quite a long way from Haputale though, so you should plan at least 2 hours for the visit.

From our accomodation in Haputale, it didn't take long to get to the top of Lipton's Seat. The drive up (yes, if you have a car and a chauffeur, its recommended that you drive up), is spectacular as we were treated to beautiful vistas of tea plantation and blue tinged mountains. We got to the top at about 10am and as most travellers had commented, the mist prevented us from enjoying one part of the view. The locals say that 5am to 8am would be the best time really but that would have been too early for us. However, the other non-misty side was gorgeous as well, so we stayed and enjoyed the beauty and greenery, while sharing a cuppa with Sir Lipton! I did see some people trekking down the tea plantations. Am not sure how practical that is but our guide said that there is a really high chance of leeches sticking to you if you take that path. So I would choose to be less adventurous and take a tuk tuk or a car up and down Lipton's Seat. This is a definite highlight of our Sri Lankan trip and its highly recommended.

This place is marvelous but it gets covered with fog very very early in the morning. We read reviews on TripAdvisor saying that being on top at 9 o'clock is fine. Well, from our experience I disagree. It is way too late. We took the earliest train from Ella leaving at 6.40am. We arrived in Haputale at 7.40am. The train cost 25rs, third class, no reservation. From Haputale we rushed to Lipton's Seat with a tuk tuk (about 30 mins trip, 800rs). When we reached the top the whole place was already covered with fog. I therefore recommend to spend the night before in or near Haputale and get a tuk tuk aiming to reach Lipton's Seat for no later than 7am. Entrance fee is 50rs. On our way back we walked down to Dambatenne Tea Factory. Amazing 2 hours  walk (slow pace to enjoy the scenery) After an interesting visit to the tea factory we took a bus to Haputale (30rs).
Definitely worth it although don't depend on the tea factory to give you a tour. Just enjoy the walk and the views.

This is a beautiful location. Recommend to get to this place before 8 a.m. in the morning cos if the mist set in you would not be able to see much. I went there with my wife and five year old daughter. On your way you can visit Dambetenna tea factory as well which is over 100 years old.
Visit this place early in the morning, you can spend the day till evening with bit cold climate. Can have lunch from small restaurant, but need to free order.

There's a long, windy drive to the Seat but it's worth it.  Best to get there before the fog rolls in around 8am.  However, we got there a little later and the fog came and went, so we still had a chance to see the amazing views.

Very nice place worth to visit, it is good to take the walk from the bus up or a walk down from the top. The way there is offering very nice landscapes and views. On the top you can have a real Lipton tea and also some food for a good price. Try to visit the Liptons seat in the early morning to have good view, arround 10 am it starts to be foggy and you will miss the best views/panoramas.

This place is situated 15 km away from the Haputale town. We have go through very narrow road climbing the hill. But this is very interesting journey. At the top of the place we can observe five areas belongs to Southern, Uwa, Sabagamuwa and Central provinces.

It's 7km from the tea factory at the bottom to the view at the top. Easy walk. Took us (fit but not active 20-somethings) about an hour and a half. 50Rs "per soul" for the last few hundred meters. You can also get a car or three wheeler all the way to the top if you don't want to walk (three wheeler from Haputale 600Rs to the bottom or 1000Rs to the top). I'd recommend walking to the top if you can. You pass through the village where the plantation workers live then through the fields where they work. BUT YOU MUST REACH THE TOP BEFORE 9AM otherwise the view will be obscured by clouds. Nice little tea shop at the top with local snacks.
Great place to visit ..its the highest area of Haputale , Diyatalawa area.  have very adventures bends road some places little bit difficult to change two vehicles...carefully driven

I booked the tuk tuk service by my guesthouse, the boss charged me Rs.1300 and turn out I bargained to Rs.1000 one way to catch the sunrise. I searched online that could be Rs.800 but just didn't wanna bother to walk around and ask the price. So just deal. The tuk tuk driver dropped us off in front of the gate instead to the top of the Lipton's Seat. I thought he just cheated. But as the sun was rising, he brought us into the tea field and had a very good place and aspect to see the sunrise! He was correct as Lipton's Seat is not exactly facing the East. After watching sunrise, I and my friend walked to Lipton's Seat, it was about 1km from the gate, around 15 mins walk. Of course there are plenty of shortcut in the tea field, you could go up and down faster if you could find it. If not, just follow the main road. It was around 7am when we arrived Lipton's Seat, the view was amazing. The store at the top opened at 730 or 8am, can't remember. We haven't ordered anything, the staff just told us to take a seat, and he gave us 2 hot tea and 3-4 roti. Rs200 in total. We walked down to the Lipton factory afterwards, it took us about 2 hours. On the way I saw there was a bus heading to Lipton Seat. I thought it was a tour bus because I didn't see any info of any bus directly goes to Lipton's Seat from Haputale. After we arrived the factory, we caught the bus which was from the Lipton's Seat. It was Rs35-40/ person, and dropped off at the Haputale town centre. I asked the staff who collected money that if the bus headed directly to the top of Lipton's Seat. And he said yes. The schedule was 30min an interval. I dropped off at 9:50 and he told me the next bus was 10:30 Hope the info could help.

It is less touristy which we like most. Slow scenic drive through narrow streets, waving to villagers, activities on the tea plantation. When we reached Lipton seat, we enjoyed a cup of tea in a very local cafe.

The trek up tot he attraction takes about 35min in a vehicle/tuk tuk maybe longer to hike if you like. Get's crowded during seasons. Best time to see the sunrise is just before 5.45-6.15AM and I guess the sunset look equally gorgeous too. A Rs.50 ticket needs to be obtained at the gate. A tuk tuk may cost anything between rs.1200-1500 but these guys know how to get there. If in Haputale a must visit. Can be chilly earlier in the morning so be geared up
Narrow misty road.to get the best shots go there in the morning when sun rises. dont forget to bring your long distance shooting lenses

Worth getting there before 6am. We were the first to arrive at 5:30 am to see the sunrise, and by 6am there were about 3 other couples. There is a small shop at the top serving tea, rotti and wadey. For the return trip you can walk through the tea plantation to Dmabatenna factory (about 8Km) and take the bus to Haputhale.

From Living Heritage at Koslanda we took an early morning trip to Liptons Seat and the Dambatenne Tea Factory - you need to get to Liptons Seat early for the best light and views - we left at about 6/6:30 and arrived around 9 for stunningly vivid skies and tea bushes and far reaching views. Definitely worth an early start - we enjoyed a cup of tea at the little cafe shack next to the view point. Some people were walking up to / down from the Seat - looked a pretty tough trek in the heat & sun, no shade available the roads were steep & windy, car was definitely the right option for us!

The Lipton's seat is a must see, if you travel to the middle of the island! Either you can walk up the hill few kilometers through the tea fields, or take a tuktuk, negotiate the price, we went up for 500lkr. The way down is nice walk! I would recommend go up in the morning, bigger chance to have a nice weather. The view on top is stunning! They also serve tea and some Sri Lankan brunch. The little boy waiter was actually the best, most polite and fastest waiter on the island!! You should also visit Dambatene tea factory on the way back. Don't forget to bring some school pens for local kids :)
Amazing view especialy when you catch the sunrise! On the top is the small cottage where you can get te tea and delicios (spicy) breakfast.

I always visit this place.beautiful place. And very clean. From hapurale to dabatenne tea factory we can go by car. Then after tea factory little bit difficult to drive. And after dabatenne tea factry have nice tea plantation. Amazing view. On top you can see Udawalawa national park aria. Thanks Chin

One of the Best view points we have ever been. Beautiful walk up there trough tea plantages with great scenery and amazing views all around. You can have tea,  coffee and simple breakfast there (quite expensive which is obvious for such a nice place). I recommend to go there early morning in this period of the year (end of march) because of usual heavy rain in the afternoon.

This is really worth doing. The drive to and from this viewpoint is breathtaking. Its such a scenic area and steeped in colonial history.  There is a small tea room when you get to the top. Some crazy people were hiking the route up to the view point.

Our mini-bus could go only as far as the Dambatenna tea factory. A public bus service is also available upto this point from the Haputale Town. From there a 7 km trip by tuk tuk (charge Rs 800), mostly up the mountain. Small vans and cars can also do that part of the journey. On a clear day there is a 360 degree view of the mountain country from the top where Thomas Lipton used to entertain his guests. It's a pity there are no toilets at the site. The Dambatenne Tea Factory provided that facility to visitors but the toilet floors were flooded and there was no water in the taps.
Look when you are there, its a beautifull area with hight mountains, lot off birth and very nice flowers, you have to start early morning
