Had an absolutely great walk to this viewpoint from Dambatenne tea factory, some 5-6 km. Important to do it in the morning - as we were coming down, first clouds appeared and by midday you probably have no view at all!!

We got here just in time for sunrise and boy was it worth it! It was worth the entire trouble of getting off bed at 4.00 am and trekking up the tea plantation to get to this one of a kind place. At almost 2000m above sea level , you could see 1/3 of the island from this point ( on a clear day ). I stood speechless looking at the sunrise and soaking in every bit of it. Hats off to Mr Thomas Lipton for discovering this view point and highly recommend anyone to visit this place ( it's a must visit ) P.s wait around till 7am so you could have a fresh cupa tea (that's the time the tea shop opens ).

I think this place is the best to view the most of the sri lanka. Path is quite long and try to bring a vehicle unless you like to walk. There is a tea place on top of this place. Prices are expensive in there. Make sure you check the prices before you buy something to eat or drink. Best way to reach this place is via Haputhale. The road via Bandarawela is bit rough.

We got a three wheeler to the entrance gate (50/- per soul as the sign says).  We walked the last 1.5kms admiring the view.  When you get to the top the view is stunning and easily as good as Worlds End at Horton Plains which costs a lot more.  There's a tea stand at the top which is welcome and they have short eats. A few monkeys came by and were swiftly chased off by the tea man. Then we walked down to the Dambatenne factory through the tea gardens by way of the paths that cut through them. It was a lovely walk with fantastic views. We didn't visit the factory as we'd been to Uve Halpewatte.  Just next to the bus stop there's a little shop where you can get a cup of tea.  The shopkeeper is very chatty and we spent a nice half hour with him.  Then we got the bus back to Haputale (fare about 30/-). This was a really great trip.

We made the mistake of getting a tuk tuk to the top, don't bother! The walk is quite easy and leisurely and you have some really nice views on the way. We actually agreed a return price to the bottom but instead paid him less and walked back ourselves to enjoy the view. Nice little cafe at the top where you can have a cup of tea (I assume Liptons) and look out over all the tea plantations. Also really easy and cheap to travel to via bus, although as always the local may deceive you about the public transport in order for you to pay far more in their mode of transportation. Worth a look

"Lipton¬¥s Seat" is a great view point and the drive until there is fantastic.We had been lucky the day before in Ella to have met a tuk tuk driver who convinced us to do this excursion.We met early in the morning at 7 o¬¥clock and it took us two hours drive ( only one way) through mountain lonely roads.We stopped several times to take photos of magnificent landscapes,small villages and the tea pickers ladies that we met driving through tea plantations,finally around 9 o¬¥clock we reached Lipton¬¥s¬¥seat and enjoyed a clear view (everybody says that it is better to go early because later it is usually foggy.")then we came down the other side of the mountain with the tuk tuk towards Haputale and at 12 o¬¥clock we took the train to Ella.(If you want to get a coffee and eat a cake in a clean place we recommend "Glaze Pastry & Bakery" at the Olympus Plaza Hotel. On our opinion, In Haputale you will not find a better place).
From its vantage point, you can see a large portion of Southern Sri Lanka, with an incredibly panoramic vista.  Worth visiting.

That was a great trip to Lipton's seat. You can see all the tea plants and workers and once you reach the summit there is a gorgeous view in front of you. Of course you can by a cup tea there as well. Definitely highly recommended to visit this place.

It would be the best to take a tuktuk for a ride up and then take a hike down to the factory because of the sun and the heat. Anyway, you will get an amazing view on the plantations and get to see and meet the locals working and living there. I had a guide who was very informative and I had an insight to kindergarden and to the hindu temple inside of the village. The factory tour costs 250 lkr and it was worth the visit - also guided. It was absolutely stunning. I would recommend it to all.

Many of tripadvisor readers knew why this place called lipton's seat. So i'm not going to say it again. We visit this place as a part of our annual college friends trip. You have to buy tickets atvtwo places, one when you enter to dambetenne estate and another one from the entrance gate for the road to lipton's seat. Roads are repairing at the moment when we went there. So as a result of it, it takes more time to pass that 12kms. Strongly advice you to travel with the vehicle with 4WD. and be careful when you pass those tight bends. Talking about the place, the place was awesome. Nice climate. But if you were lucky you can see the view.  Must say this is the place everyone visit at least once.

Due to time constraints and creaking knees we travelled up by tuktuk. Thoroughly worthwhile and enjoyable but best of all was the tea shop at the top - great, freshly made food and tea, lovely enterprising owner so sorry I don't know the name but it is the only outlet there and still striving so hard to provide lovely refreshments.

We rode our trusty Enfield motorbikes up the windy roads to Lipton's Seat. The view is very spectacular across endless tea plantations. I suspect the views would be better in morning as was a little hazy in the afternoon. If you drive the roads are tight with limited parking and a good 3 point turn at the top to get back.

Let me start by saying its better if you hike up rather than drive on this narrow estate road which is what I did. But the trip up is definitly worth the view and the hot tea and eats that you can have at the small boutique at the top. I would recomend that you got there early morning.

Fantastic view but a long and steep hike without shade. We tok a tuk-tuk from Dambatenne tea factory,  worth it IF you are not very fit. You can easily walk back to haputale along the little trafficked road, through plantations and small Villages Just flag down a bus if you get tired

Leaving the bus in front of the dambatenne tea factory we thought it would be close - well, really - wasn't;) It's over 5km walk up through the tea fields - absolutely lovely, with the kids going to school, tea pickers working and villages living their normal life. The view gets clouded after 10 am - make sure you get there early!

We went there at about 11 o'clock with a tuc tuc to the top (tuc tuc from hotel to the top 800 rp). The last 1 km you need to walk and Pay entrance fee 50 rp/pp. On the top there is a great view. Local people serve you a drink on the top...you must try this experience. On the way down we walked approx. 5 km. Then we went down with bus (30 rp/pp).

If you want to walk the tee plantation and meet local people in unspoiled way, you should walk the liptons sit at least in one direction. Bring school pens for children you meet on the way. Don't give money or sweet not to spoil the experiance.
Amazing place ,panoramic views  and hectic journey though plantations.road was narrow and better taking a tuk tuk. Try to catch sunrise if you can by reaching early. It will be a memorable view.

One of my favourite trips in Sri Lanka! Due to my leg injury I was forced to take the tuk tuk here, but it was still nice experience. I wish i could have done at least few km walking, because the area is pinturesque, full of nice tea plantations. Fully recommendable!

Amazing place. We started walking up to Liptons seat from the tea factory around 5.30. It was still dark by the time we started, but the sunrise on our way to the summit was very nice. The ascendant took us less then 1,5 hours and was not that exhausting. By the time we reached Liptons seat we had it all to our selves. After descending, we visited the tea factory. That was nice, but not very special.

This is a must visit place if you are in or around Haputale. This is sort of 360 viewing point. Road is bit hectic through tea plantation but it is worthy price to pay. If you travel early in the morning you can see the sunrise.
this is a awesome place it's about 18km from haputhale junction on the way to  lipton seat you'll see some nice view's of mountain ranges

It is not a casual stroll up to Lipton's Seat , that is why many people choose to go up by car or tuk tuk. But if you are able and can walk up hill for 2 hours, do it ! We met so many lovely people on the way - it was a Saturday so the kids were not at school and ran out onto the road to talk to us. If you go - take loads of cheap biros as that is all they want ! As you go further up you then begin to meet the workers and tea pluckers. Smile and say hello first and you will be rewarded with lovely Sri Lankan smiles back and attempts to speak to you in English.The views as you ascend are magnificent and that is why if, as happened to us the mist descends when you reach the peak it doesn't really matter as you saw so much beautiful scenery on the way. When you get to the top the chaotic but friendly cafe - hut will serve you a cup of .... Lipton's tea . Sit down with your cuppa and enjoy the view . We decided to take a tuk tuk down as the uphill climb had worn us out . But tuk tuk driver happy to stop for photos on the way down.
